HASTEN.deftext:
to go quickly, speed, hurry; speed up

Note the pronunciation. The t is silent.

To HASTEN is to move or act quickly.

“The policeman HASTENED to the scene of the crime.”

“He HASTENED to add that the price did not include the tax.”

To HASTEN something is to speed it up, to make it go faster.

“The general tried to HASTEN the enemy’s defeat by sending more soldiers into the battle.”

HASTE is quickness or speed, especially careless speed.

“In his HASTE to leave he forgot to take his jacket.”

Something which is HASTY is done quickly, often too quickly.

“They decided to have a party at the last minute, and then made some HASTY preparations for it.”

Other forms of the word: HASTE, n. HASTY, adj.

FAMINE.deftext:
an extreme shortage of food

A FAMINE is a severe lack of food in an area.

“When it didn’t rain for months, the crops all died, and FAMINE resulted.”

FAMINE is also occasionally used about severe shortages of other kinds of things.

“The charity was suffering from a FAMINE of contributions; no one was giving it any money.”

A related adjective is FAMISHED, which means extremely hungry, starving.

“After six days without food we were FAMISHED.”

Other forms of the word: FAMISHED,adj.

EXCURSION.deftext:
a short journey, pleasure trip; a digression

See ex- under Prefixes. An EXCURSION is a short trip, usually made for pleasure as part of a group, with the intention of returning to the starting point.

“We had a pleasant EXCURSION to the country last weekend.”

“They made their annual EXCURSION to the seashore.”

EXCURSION is also occasionally used to mean digression, a brief departure from the main idea or the main goal.

“We could never follow him when he went off on one of his EXCURSIONS into higher mathematics.”

DERANGED.deftext:
crazy, insane

To DERANGE something is to put it out of proper order, to disarrange it. As an adjective, DERANGED is used about people whose minds are not working properly, and means insane.

“The DERANGED man wandered across the highway in the middle of rush hour.”

“The DERANGED killer said that he heard voices telling him whom to murder.”

The most common wrong answer on the Pretest is unhappy. Great sorrow can sometimes cause a person to become DERANGED, but someone who is unhappy is not necessarily insane.

Other forms of the word: DERANGE,v.

DECREE.deftext:
an order, edict

A DECREE is an order, given by a ruler, judge, or anyone in power, which is to be obeyed just like a law.

“The king’s DECREE that property taxes were to be raised did not increase his popularity.”

“We tried every way we could think of to get around Dad’s DECREE that we were to be in bed by nine o’clock.”

DECREE is also a verb which means “to give an order.”

“The judge DECREED that the company had to rehire the two employees.”

LEGIBLE.deftext:
readable

See -able under Suffixes. The leg part of the word is from a Latin word meaning to read. Something which is LEGIBLE is able to be read easily, is clear and plain.

“Her handwriting was small but LEGIBLE.”

“The sign was so covered over with dirt that it was barely LEGIBLE.”

The opposite of LEGIBLE is ILLEGIBLE, not readable.

“He signed his name so quickly that it was completely ILLEGIBLE.”

Sensible is often chosen as the meaning of LEGIBLE. Something can be LEGIBLE, however, and not make any sense.

Other forms of the word: LEGIBILITY, n.

GRANDEUR.deftext:
greatness, majesty, magnificence, splendor

GRANDEUR comes from the word grand. GRANDEUR is greatness, impressiveness. The word is used about people and things.

“He admired the GRANDEUR of those ancient kings.”

“The GRANDEUR of the magnificent scenery left us all in awe.”

“His ideas had a certain GRANDEUR, but he never had enough money to carry them out.”

ENUNCIATE.deftext:
to declare, proclaim, state definitely; pronounce, utter

ENUNCIATE is from the same Latin word as pronunciation and renunciation. All have to do with speaking out or declaring something. ENUNCIATE has two somewhat different uses. One meaning is “to state or declare in a formal way.”

“Jefferson was among the first to ENUNCIATE the principles of representative government.”

“He ENUNCIATED his grand theory of the universe.”

The second use is simply to pronounce, to utter.

“He ENUNCIATED his words carefully.”

“You must learn to ENUNCIATE clearly.”

In both senses the basic idea is speaking out.

Other forms of the word: ENUNCIATION, n.

DECIPHER.deftext:
to make out the meaning of, decode

One meaning of the word CIPHER is a code. To DECIPHER something is to take it out of its code and make it understandable. See de- under Prefixes.

“The army DECIPHERED the enemy’s top-secret messages.”

DECIPHER also means “to make out the meaning of” something difficult to understand or read.

“He managed to DECIPHER the hastily written note.”

“They DECIPHERED the faint writing on the cave walls.”

MERCILESS.deftext:
without mercy, showing no pity, cruel

See -less under Suffixes. A MERCILESS person lacks MERCY or pity.

“The judge was MERCILESS in punishing criminals.”

“The other boys laughed MERCILESSLY at John’s attempt to sing.”

“The boxer kept up his MERCILESS attack until his opponent was knocked out.”

The opposite of MERCILESS is MERCIFUL, full of MERCY.

“The father decided to be MERCIFUL and not punish his son.”

Other forms of the word: MERCY, n. MERCIFUL, adj.

GLUTTON.deftext:
a person who eats too much

To GLUT something is to overfill it, to supply it with more than it needs.

“There are too many television sets for sale; the market is GLUTTED with them.”

A GLUTTON eats too much; he stuffs or gorges himself at every meal and always wants more food than is good for him.

“He was a real GLUTTON; he always had six hamburgers for lunch.”

GLUTTON can also be used about a person who never seems to have enough of something besides food. A “GLUTTON for punishment” is someone who can take a lot of punishment without giving in.

Other forms of the word: GLUT, v. GLUTTONY, n. GLUTTONOUS, adj.

ESCAPADE.deftext:
an adventure, prank, wild experience

ESCAPADE is from the same root as escape, and an old meaning of ESCAPADE was “an act of escaping.” Today the word has come to mean “an exciting adventure or action which goes against normal behavior.”

“His trip to Tahiti was a surprising ESCAPADE for such an old man.”

An ESCAPADE isn’t usually evil, but it can cause trouble.

“His childish ESCAPADES usually cost us a lot of money.”

“The foolish ESCAPADE on the boat almost caused them to drown.”

The most common mistake for the meaning of ESCAPADE is crime. An ESCAPADE could be a crime, but it generally suggests something less serious.

RANSACK.deftext:
to search thoroughly, rifle

To RANSACK something is to search through it thoroughly. RANSACK usually suggests that the searching is violent or disorderly, or for the purpose of robbery.

“He RANSACKED the house looking for his mittens.”

“The jewel thief RANSACKED the vault.”

“The invaders RANSACKED the city and took everything of value they could find.”

Many people think RANSACK means destroy, probably because of the violence often associated with RANSACKING.

FALTER.deftext:
to hesitate, waver, stumble, stagger

To FALTER is to waver or hesitate, to act uncertainly out of fear, weakness, or nervousness.

“He started the speech well, but FALTERED halfway through.”

“She never FALTERED in her drive to become a successful doctor.”

“The football team began to FALTER in the second quarter, and by the end of the game couldn’t do anything right.”

“His legs began to FALTER, and he knew he would never make it to the top of the mountain.”

The most frequently chosen wrong answer on the Pretest is change, probably because FALTER looks like alter, which means to change.

DISPEL.deftext:
to drive away, scatter, clear away

See dis- under Prefixes. The pel part of DISPEL means to drive or push. To impel is to drive forward; to repel is to drive back. To DISPEL is to drive away. DISPEL is used more about emotions and states of mind than about actual physical objects.

“His arguments DISPELLED any remaining doubts they had about the plan.”

“The teacher DISPELLED any illusions he might have had about passing the course.”

“Bill’s reassurances couldn’t DISPEL her feeling that someone was following them.”

questions.prompt: Do HASTY decisions take a lot of thought?
Would people die during a FAMINE?
If you moved to Japan, would that be an EXCURSION?
Would GRANDEUR usually be a quality of a king's palace?
Should an actor be able to ENUNCIATE clearly?
Is it possible to DECIPHER a message sent in a simple code?
Does a MERCILESS person take pity on others?
Can you fix a wobbly chair by RANSACKING it?
If something FALTERS, does it go straight to the end without stopping?
George HASTENED to his mother's bedside when he heard that she was dying.
It was such a pleasant FAMINE that they decided to do it every week.
They went on a brief EXCURSION into the city one morning.
He claimed he was DERANGED when he committed the crime and therefore wasn't responsible for his actions.
The principal DECREED that there would be no running in the school corridors.
The teacher refused to accept homework which was not LEGIBLE.
He felt that nothing could compare with the GRANDEUR of the Rocky Mountains.
The founder ENUNCIATED the rules by which the organization would be governed.
He had such poor handwriting that it was impossible to DECIPHER his letters.
The author was upset by the MERCILESS criticism of his new book.
He was such a GLUTTON that he couldn't go two steps without tripping.
On Halloween all the children joined in various harmless ESCAPADES.
During the battle we RANSACKED the enemy with our bombers.
I couldn't FALTER him for the way he acted; I would have done the same thing myself.
The senator tried to DISPEL the rumors that he was running for president.

SKEPTIC.deftext:
a doubter, unbeliever

A SKEPTIC is inclined to question the value or truth of things. He doubts everything, and trusts or believes in nothing.

“He was a SKEPTIC when it came to believing the promises of politicians.”

“She was unable to convince those SKEPTICS that she really did mean what she said.”

The adjective form is SKEPTICAL, which means doubting. “She was very SKEPTICAL about the plan’s chances for success.”

“He was SKEPTICAL of his brother’s loyalty.”

Other forms of the word: SKEPTICAL, adj. SKEPTICISM, n.

Usage: SKEPTIC is sometimes spelled sceptic.

EXPLICIT.deftext:
clear, clearly expressed, definite, outspoken

See ex- under Prefixes. The root meaning of EXPLICIT is folded out. Something which is EXPLICIT is open to view like a piece of paper all folded out. EXPLICIT instructions are fully given and leave no room for misunderstanding. An EXPLICIT belief is clearly developed and fully understood. A person who is EXPLICIT says exactly what he means.

“He gave us EXPLICIT orders not to leave the room.”

“She was EXPLICIT about the need for complete obedience.”

The opposite of EXPLICIT is implicit. Something which is implicit is not clearly expressed; it is only hinted at or implied.

“Although he didn’t actually say so, we thought it was implicit that he agreed with us.”

RURAL.deftext:
country, rustic

RURAL means “having to do with the country"-as opposed to the city.

“The mountains and lakes in the RURAL areas of the state attract many visitors from the cities.”

“Is the RURAL population growing or declining?”

“I prefer RURAL life to city life. People are much friendlier in the country.”

Most people who misunderstand this word confuse it with its opposite, and think it means city.

REFUGE.deftext:
protection, shelter

REFUGE is shelter or protection from something that threatens or troubles you.

“We found REFUGE from the storm in an old barn.”

“He sought REFUGE from his worries in music.”

A REFUGE is also the place that gives a person or animal shelter.

“The house was a REFUGE for stray cats and dogs.”

A REFUGEE is a person who flees his own country because of war, political trouble, or the like, and seeks safety in another country.

“Thousands of REFUGEES poured across the border when the war broke out.”

Other forms of the word: REFUGEE, n.

THERMAL.deftext:
of heat, caused by heat

See -al under Suffixes. The therm part of THERMAL means heat; it is also found in the word thermometer, which is an instrument that measures how hot something is. THERMAL means “having to do with heat or temperature.”

“They used the hot water of the THERMAL springs as a source of THERMAL power.”

GESTURE.deftext:
a movement of the body, motion

A GESTURE is a movement of a part of the body, usually the hands or the head, which shows a thought, idea, or feeling.

“He reached out his hand in a GESTURE of friendship.”

“He had lost his voice, so he had to get his idea across by means of GESTURES.”

GESTURE can also be used in a general way to indicate an action done for show or as a symbol of something else.

“In a GESTURE of protest the workers refused to speak to their boss.”

“She offered to buy the car for him, but it was a meaningless GESTURE, since she knew he wouldn’t let her.”

Reply is the most commonly chosen incorrect answer. A GESTURE can be used as a reply to someone, but it is used in many other situations as well.

WAGER.deftext:
to bet

WAGER means to bet.

“I WAGER that he will be successful in his new job.”

“How much do you have to WAGER to stay in the poker game?”

WAGER is also a noun meaning a bet.

“He placed a WAGER of five dollars on the horse race.”

“Each day she made a WAGER with herself that she would get to work on time.”

Many people think WAGER means to earn. You may make money as the result of a WAGER, but you earn money by working, not by betting.

INQUISITIVE.deftext:
curious, prying

INQUISITIVE is related to the word inquire, which means to ask. Someone who is INQUISITIVE likes to inquire about things.

“He had an INQUISITIVE mind. He was curious about the reasons for everything.”

The word is often used in a bad sense, about someone who is too curious about the affairs of other people.

“She answered his questions until she thought he was becoming too INQUISITIVE, and then she refused to say any more.”

“He pulled the shade so that his experiment would be safe from the eyes of INQUISITIVE reporters.”

Friendly and talkative are both often picked as the meaning of INQUISITIVE. An INQUISITIVE person might have both these qualities, but his basic characteristic would be curiosity.

UNSAVORY.deftext:
distasteful, nasty, disgusting

Something which is SAVORY is pleasant tasting or smelling.

“He could smell the SAVORY odor of the apple pie as it cooked.”

UNSAVORY means not savory, distasteful, disgusting. See un- under Prefixes.

“She felt sick the first time she had the UNSAVORY task of cleaning an infected wound.”

The word is usually used about people or things that are morally disgusting.

“He was led astray by UNSAVORY companions.”

“There is a great deal of truth in the UNSAVORY stories about him.”

EMERGE.deftext:
to come out, come into view; to become known

In its original meaning, EMERGE was an exact opposite of submerge. When you EMERGE you rise up out of the water; when you submerge you sink or plunge beneath the surface of the water. The word now means to come out or come into view the way something does when it rises from water. See ex- under Prefixes.

“The men EMERGED from the cave.”

“The sun EMERGED from behind a cloud.”

EMERGE can also be used with ideas or facts or problems, in the sense of to appear, to become known.

“No new solutions EMERGED during the discussion.”

The most commonly chosen incorrect answer for EMERGED on the Pretest is went in, which is an exact opposite.

ADJACENT.deftext:
nearby, neighboring

When two things are ADJACENT to each other they are nearby; they are close together but do not necessarily touch or have a common border.

“The Andersons would like to reserve two ADJACENT rooms, one for themselves and one for their three children.”

“We were able to rent a parking space in the lot ADJACENT to our building.”

“The man in the ADJACENT apartment always left his door wide open.”

In geometry, ADJACENT angles do indeed touch each other, having one side in common.

REPEL.deftext:
to drive back, drive away; to cause distaste

See re- under Prefixes. To REPEL someone is to drive him back or away. The word is used about a person or group fighting off an attack.

“We REPELLED the robbers by throwing rocks at them.”

“The mayor REPELLED their attempt to force him out of office.”

REPEL also means “to cause distaste"-that is, to force someone away by being offensive.

“His dirty appearance REPELS many people.”

“I am REPELLED by the idea of telling a lie.”

The adjective from REPEL is REPELLENT, which means “tending to REPEL or drive away,” disgusting.

“Many people find this movie REPELLENT.”

Fight is the most common mistake made on the Pretest. Fight would often be used in the same situation as REPEL, but you could fight someone without managing to REPEL him.

Other forms of the word: REPELLENT, adj., n.

SURMOUNT.deftext:
to overcome, rise above, get over

The prefix sur- means over. The mount part of the word SURMOUNT is related to mountain. To SURMOUNT something is to climb over or rise above it. The word is especially applied to overcoming obstacles and problems.

“She SURMOUNTED every difficulty on her way to becoming a doctor.”

“He managed to SURMOUNT the temptation to eat another piece of pie.”

“It is difficult to SURMOUNT the lack of a good education.”

EXECUTE.deftext:
to carry out, fulfill, put into effect; to put to death

To EXECUTE something is to carry it out as you have planned or as you have been told to do.

“They EXECUTED the plan perfectly"-that is, they carried it out with no mistakes.

“They EXECUTED the officer’s orders without a complaint.”

“The football team tried to EXECUTE a trick plan.”

The most common use of EXECUTE is to EXECUTE a prisoner, to carry out a legal sentence of death on someone.

“They EXECUTED the criminal because of the brutal murders he had committed.”

Other forms of the word: EXECUTION, n.

RATIFY.deftext:
to approve, confirm, make valid

To RATIFY something is to confirm it or make it legal by giving your approval. The word is used about laws, treaties, agreements, actions, and so on.

“Congress will have to RATIFY the treaty before it will go into effect.”

“The union members refused to RATIFY the contract with the company.”

Other forms of the word: RATIFICATION, n.

questions.prompt: Is it hard to trick a SKEPTIC?
Is it easy to be confused by EXPLICIT directions?
Is a RURAL area likely to be full of factories and traffic?
Is an open field a REFUGE in a heavy rain?
Is THERMAL underwear supposed to keep you warm?
Do you have to use your hand to make a GESTURE?
Can you lose money by WAGERING?
Is a newspaper reporter supposed to be INQUISITIVE?
Would most people like to do business with UNSAVORY characters?
Does the sun EMERGE when it goes behind a cloud?
Is Los Angeles ADJACENT to New York?
Would an insect REPELLENT attract bugs?
Can you usually SURMOUNT an obstacle by ignoring it?
Does RATIFYING a decision show that it displeases you?
Ever since he lied to me, I am inclined to be SKEPTICAL of anything he says.
Alice was quite EXPLICIT about her complaints. She told everyone exactly what was wrong.
He felt RURAL whenever he was by himself for very long.
She thought of her home as a place of REFUGE from the troubles of the world.
A glider depends on rising THERMAL air currents to keep it up.
With a thumbs-down GESTURE he showed his disapproval of their plan.
Bill refused to WAGER on the horse race; he said he never won bets like that.
He's very INQUISITIVE: making money is all he thinks about.
People came from miles around just to get a taste of her UNSAVORY cooking.
The bear EMERGED from the cave after hibernating all winter.
They sat in ADJACENT seats in the hall so that they could talk to each other.
The defending army was prepared to REPEL the invaders.
She SURMOUNTED a painting over the fireplace.
The idea was good, but they EXECUTED it so poorly that the whole plan failed.
The teacher RATIFIED us that we had passed the exam.

APPRENTICE.deftext:
a beginner, learner

An APPRENTICE is a person who learns a trade or skill by working with someone who already knows it. Thus, an APPRENTICE is a learner or beginner.

“Before becoming a good carpenter or plumber, you must spend several years as an APPRENTICE in order to learn the work.”

“Although she was just an APPRENTICE, she was quite skillful at doing electrical repairs.”

Other forms of the word: APPRENTICESHIP, n.

NOMAD.deftext:
wanderer, roamer

A NOMAD is a person who moves around constantly without settling in one spot. Usually the word is used in connection with tribes or groups of people who move about in search of food or grazing lands.

“The Bedouins of North Africa are NOMADS who wander from place to place with their camels, sheep, and goats.”

“After they invaded the city, the NOMADS settled down to a different way of life.”

NOMAD is also used about anyone who travels about constantly.

“The workers lived like NOMADS, going anywhere in the country their company needed them.”

Other forms of the word: NOMADIC, adj.

REPRESS.deftext:
to hold back, keep down, control, subdue

See re- under Prefixes. To REPRESS something is to hold it back, to keep it under control. The word is used especially about feelings or actions that are controlled by an effort of the will.

“She REPRESSED a desire to speak up.”

“He REPRESSED a smile as he listened to the boy recite the poem.”

In a stronger sense, REPRESS can mean “to put down by force,” to subdue.

“The army was sent to REPRESS all rioting in the area.”

Usually, however, this sense is better expressed by the word suppress.

Other forms of the word: REPRESSION, n. REPRESSIVE, adj.

ILLUMINATE.deftext:
to brighten, light up; to make clear

See in-1 under Prefixes and -ate1 under Suffixes. The root lumin in the word ILLUMINATE means light; it is also found in the word luminous. To ILLUMINATE means to put light on or in an object or space.

“The ballroom was ILLUMINATED by hundreds of glowing candles.”

“She decided to ILLUMINATE her paintings with spotlights that were hung from the ceiling.”

ILLUMINATE can also mean to make clear or help explain-that is, to shed light upon an idea or subject.

“The English professor had a remarkable way of ILLUMINATING difficult passages in the book so that we could easily understand what we had read.”

“The meaning of a word can be ILLUMINATED by using the word in several different sentences.”

Other forms of the word: ILLUMINATION, n.

PUNCTUAL.deftext:
prompt, on time

PUNCTUAL comes from the Latin word for point or dot. A person or thing that is PUNCTUAL arrives right on the dot, is not late or tardy.

“Because John is always PUNCTUAL, he spends a lot of time waiting for others to show up.”

“I always try to be PUNCTUAL, but sometimes I’m late anyway.”

“The class starts PUNCTUALLY at nine o’clock.”

Other forms of the word: PUNCTUALITY, n.

SURVEILLANCE.deftext:
close watch, observation

SURVEILLANCE is a close watch that is maintained on a person who is suspected of being involved in a crime, or who needs to be watched for some other reason.

“The man who was suspected of being a dope peddler was kept under SURVEILLANCE by the police.”

“The government kept the foreign agent under SURVEILLANCE while he was in the country.”

“The staff had to maintain a strict SURVEILLANCE of all the patients in the mental hospital.”

FABRICATE.deftext:
to make up, invent, create

The basic meaning of FABRIC is “something that is put together,” a product of building or construction. To FABRICATE something is to make or produce it. See -ate1 under Suffixes.

“They FABRICATED the bridge using whatever material was on hand.”

When used about what people say, the word means to make up something false, in order to deceive.

“He FABRICATED the account of his travels in Europe.”

“The teacher thought his excuse was completely FABRICATED and she didn’t believe a word of it.”

In this sense, the word FABRICATION means “made up,” a lie.

“His story about winning the lottery was a FABRICATION.”

Other forms of the word: FABRIC, n. FABRICATION, n.

FELON.deftext:
a criminal

A FELON is a person who commits a serious crime, like murder or armed robbery, for which he could be sent to prison for a long time. Such a crime is called a FELONY. A FELONY is contrasted in law with a misdemeanor, which is a less serious offense (like speeding in a car) for which you usually don’t get sent to prison.

“The convicted FELON found it difficult to get a job when he got out of prison.”

“The judge made the FELONS pay back the people they had robbed.”

Other forms of the word: FELONIOUS, adj. FELONY, n.

PERPETUAL.deftext:
endless, everlasting, eternal; constant, continual

PERPETUAL means lasting forever.

“He hoped for PERPETUAL happiness in heaven after he died.”

“The old man longed for a drug that would give him PERPETUAL youth.”

In a similar sense, PERPETUAL also means constant, not stopping.

“They are PERPETUALLY fighting. They never get along.”

“It’s a PERPETUAL problem. We may never solve it.”

To PERPETUATE something is to make it PERPETUAL, to keep it from being ended or forgotten.

“They built a monument to PERPETUATE the memory of his great deeds.”

Other forms of the word: PERPETUATE, v. PERPETUITY, n.

REVOLT.deftext:
a rebellion, uprising

A REVOLT is an uprising against the government.

“The people rose in REVOLT against the cruel king.”

“The soldiers quickly put down the REVOLT.”

A REVOLT can also be any kind of refusal to accept authority.

“The young people were in REVOLT against the beliefs of their parents.”

REVOLT is also a verb.

“They REVOLTED against their rulers.”

Sometimes, the verb can mean to disgust.

“The filth in the house REVOLTED him.”

Trouble is the most commonly chosen incorrect answer in the Pretest. REVOLT, however, is much more specific than that. A REVOLT is a rebellion.

METROPOLIS.deftext:
a large city

A METROPOLIS is a large or great city. The word is formed from two Greek words meaning mother and city. Originally a METROPOLIS was a “mother-city"-one which sent people to start colonies or new cities. Now the word is used for any large, busy city.

“The explorers discovered a thriving METROPOLIS in the middle of the jungle.”

“New York has been a METROPOLIS for over a hundred years.”

Other forms of the word: METROPOLITAN, adj.

NOOK.deftext:
a corner or recess, an out-of-the-way place

A NOOK is a corner or recess in a house or a room, a small alcove. NOOK is also used for any out-of-the-way spot.

“They found a quiet little NOOK in the crowded room where they could talk.”

“He sat in a shady NOOK at the far end of the garden.”

“She sat in her usual NOOK by the fireplace.”

REFRAIN.deftext:
to hold back, abstain

TO REFRAIN from something is to keep from doing it, to hold back. See re- under Prefixes.

“Try to REFRAIN from interrupting me while I’m speaking.”

“The neighbors asked him to REFRAIN from playing the drums after midnight.”

“Sue REFRAINED from shouting out the window at him despite the noise he was making.”

Usage: REFRAIN is usually followed by from.

DEVASTATE.deftext:
to ruin, lay waste to, ravage; to overwhelm

To DEVASTATE something is to ruin it completely.

“The enemy’s bombs DEVASTATED the city.”

“The region was DEVASTATED by the hurricane.”

In a slightly different use, DEVASTATE can mean to overwhelm.

“She was completely DEVASTATED by the news of her husband’s death.”

“The book gave a DEVASTATING picture of the evils of war.”

DEVASTATE is often confused with attack. An attack may cause a place to be DEVASTATED, but the words do not have the same meaning.

Other forms of the word: DEVASTATION, n.

RECEDE.deftext:
to go back, become more distant; decline

See re- under Prefixes. To RECEDE is to go back or move away. Usually this “going back” is slow or gradual.

“The land slowly RECEDED from sight as we set out to sea.”

“The flood waters began to RECEDE when the rain stopped.”

Sometimes RECEDE has the meaning “to fall to a lower level,” to decline.

“Public support of the president RECEDED as he continued to support a tax increase.”

“His financial worries began to RECEDE as his salary increased.”

Other forms of the word: RECESSION, n.

questions.prompt: Would an APPRENTICE work by himself?
Would a NOMAD build a mansion?
Is someone who is shouting and screaming REPRESSING his anger?
Do logs burning in a fireplace help to ILLUMINATE a room?
Would you be PUNCTUAL if you were half an hour late?
Do most people like to be kept under SURVEILLANCE?
Do liars FABRICATE the stories they tell?
Could you play a baseball game in a NOOK?
Would most people REFRAIN from jumping in front of a speeding car?

Do objects appear to get larger as they RECEDE?

The PUNCTUAL teenagers burned down the building on a dare.

The FELONS were kept after school for talking back to the teacher.

There was a little NOOK where she could sit and be by herself.
She came back tanned and well-rested when she REFRAINED from her summer vacation.
A DEVASTATING plague of insects stripped the trees of fruit and thoroughly ruined that year's crop.
The fear that he felt in the dark forest RECEDED with the coming of the dawn.

PERILOUS.deftext:
dangerous, hazardous

PERIL is hazard or danger.n“They faced many PERILS climbing the mountain.”

Something that is PERILOUS is full of PERIL. See -ous under Suffixes.

“The journey across the ocean was a PERILOUS one in the days of sailing ships.”

“Crossing a minefield is PERILOUS.”

“On the top floor of the burning building, they felt their situation was PERILOUS but not hopeless.”

Other forms of the word: PERIL, n.

SUBDUE.deftext:
to overcome, control, tame, curb; to quiet down, tone down

To SUBDUE is to conquer or get control of by force, threat, or by an effort of the will.

“The conquering army SUBDUED the uprising by the natives.”

“The expert rider SUBDUED the wild horse.”

“She managed to SUBDUE her desire to own a new car.”

SUBDUE can also mean “to reduce in intensity,” to quiet down.

“They SUBDUED their voices when they saw the teacher approaching.”

The adjective SUBDUED is usually used in this sense.

“The SUBDUED lighting made the restaurant appear mysterious and romantic.”

Other forms of the word: SUBDUED, adj.

COMMERCE.deftext:
trade

COMMERCE is the buying and selling of goods, especially on a large scale or between different countries.

“The shipping strike caused COMMERCE to decline.”

“Congress encouraged COMMERCE with other countries by reducing the taxes on goods coming into the United States.”

The Chamber of COMMERCE is an association which promotes trade and business activity in a particular area.

COMMERCIAL is the adjective from COMMERCE, and means “having to do with trade or business.”

“The COMMERCIAL interests in the city urged that more roads be built to carry goods to and from the factories.”

A COMMERCIAL message or COMMERCIAL is an advertisement in a radio or television program.

Other forms of the word: COMMERCIAL, adj., n.

PRELIMINARY.deftext:
introductory, preparatory

Something that is PRELIMINARY comes before something else, and usually leads up to or prepares for it. See pre- under Prefixes.

“These are just PRELIMINARY findings. The final report will be published later.”

“There were three PRELIMINARY fights before the main event.”

PRELIMINARY is also a noun.

“This test is just a PRELIMINARY. If you pass it, you have to take a much harder one.”

The most commonly marked incorrect answer on the Pretest is final, which is almost an opposite of PRELIMINARY.

BRISK.deftext:
lively, quick-moving, stimulating

BRISK means lively, quick, energetic. The word is used about the way people or things act and move, and also about people’s manners and attitudes. BRISK often suggests a liveliness that makes a person feel strong and healthy.

“The BRISK ten-minute walk made us all feel wonderful.”

“After the heavy rain, a BRISK wind dried the newly washed ground.”

“She was a BRISK, intelligent woman with plenty of plans and the energy to carry them out.”

“It was a BRISK fall day: the sun was out but it was cool and there was no humidity.”

NONCHALANT.deftext:
casual, cool, unconcerned

See non- under Prefixes. The root meaning of NONCHALANT is not warm. The word is applied to people who have a cool and calm manner, who do not get excited or upset easily.

“He seems very NONCHALANT about winning the prize, but he’s really quite pleased.”

“When she was accused of lying, she acted very NONCHALANT, as if it didn’t bother her a bit.”

Other forms of the word: NONCHALANCE, n.

DENOUNCE.deftext:
to criticize, speak against

To DENOUNCE someone is to criticize or make charges against him, usually publicly.

“He DENOUNCED his former friend as a crook and a liar.”

“She DENOUNCED the plan, calling it unfair and illegal.”

In a slightly different sense, the word means “to give in- formation against” a person, usually to the authorities.

“He DENOUNCED his co-worker to the police as a traitor.”

The noun from DENOUNCE is DENUNCIATION. “Despite the City Council’s DENUNCIATION of his plan, the mayor said he would go ahead with it.”

Other forms of the word: DENUNCIATION, n.

EARNEST.deftext:
serious, determined, sincere

An EARNEST person is sincere and serious in pursuing a goal. The word suggests steady purpose and deep feeling.

“The EARNEST student tried to learn all he could about the subject.”

“He made an EARNEST attempt to climb the mountain, but finally had to give up.”

“The teacher EARNESTLY warned Jack to study harder or else he wouldn’t graduate.”

EARNEST is also a noun, which is usually found in the phrase “in EARNEST.” Someone who is “in EARNEST” is serious, is not joking.

“She was in EARNEST when she told us a hurricane was coming and we were in danger.”

OPTIMISTIC.deftext:
hopeful, cheerful, confident

The word OPTIMIST comes from a Latin word meaning best. An OPTIMIST believes everything will turn out for the best.

“He’s such an OPTIMIST-he believes that he will soon be rich and famous.”

OPTIMISTIC is the adjective from OPTIMIST. See -ic under Suffixes. Someone who is OPTIMISTIC is hopeful and cheerful in his outlook. OPTIMISTIC people are confident that everything will turn out well, even though they may have no good reason to believe this.

“Although he knew he had only one year to live, he was OPTIMISTIC that a cure would be found in time to save him.”

“She was OPTIMISTIC about getting the job on the newspaper because the editor had seemed to like her during the interview.”

Other forms of the word: OPTIMISM, n. OPTIMIST, n.

CONQUEST.deftext:
victory, conquering

CONQUEST is related to the word CONQUER. To CONQUER is to defeat or overcome an enemy. A CONQUEST is a victory or the act of CONQUERING. The word is usually used about victory in war or battle.

“The CONQUEST of Germany was a long campaign; it took four years to CONQUER the country.”

“The Norman CONQUEST of England began with the Battle of Hastings.”

CONQUEST is also used about any act of overcoming or gaining a victory, especially after a struggle.

“Many doctors deserve credit for helping in the CONQUEST of polio.”

STERN.deftext:
severe, strict, firm, grim

Someone who is STERN has a firm and unyielding manner, is strict and severe.

“The STERN teacher would punish the whole class for any mistakes.”

STERN is also used about the way people look and what they do.

“He gave them a STERN look when he heard them laughing at him.”

“The children were unhappy because of their mother’s STERN refusal to let them play outside.”

Something which is a “STERN necessity” isn’t very pleasant, but has to be done.

“He was faced with the STERN necessity of having to fire his best friend from the job.”

BEHOLD.deftext:
to look at, observe, see

To BEHOLD something is to look at it. The word usually suggests seeing fully and clearly.

“When we first BEHELD the city we knew we wanted to live there.”

“After a snowstorm the woods are beautiful to BEHOLD.”

“Last night I BEHELD the strangest sight I have ever seen.”

“The magician opened the box and BEHOLD! the girl had disappeared.”

Many people confuse BEHOLD with remember, perhaps because the hold part of the word suggests holding something in your memory.

Usage: The past tense of BEHOLD is BEHELD.

DISCLOSE.deftext:
to reveal, uncover, expose, divulge, make known

See dis- under Prefixes. To DISCLOSE something is to make it “not closed,” to open it up to view or to public knowledge.

“Examination of their records DISCLOSED several illegal business deals.”

The word is usually used about people saying something which was previously secret.

“Jim DISCLOSED that he had once been in jail.”

The noun from DISCLOSE is DISCLOSURE.

“Everyone was shocked by his DISCLOSURE that he was an alcoholic.”

Other forms of the word: DISCLOSURE, n.

ETIQUETTE.deftext:
manners, rules of behavior

Note the pronunciation. The qu is pronounced like k.

Every society or profession has its own unwritten rules of how to behave, what to do and what not to do in certain situations. ETIQUETTE is the general name for these accepted ways of behaving.

“To leave the table so soon was not proper ETIQUETTE"-that is, it was not the accepted way to act.”

“Medical ETIQUETTE prohibits a doctor from stealing another doctor’s patient.”

It is not against the law to go against ETIQUETTE, but you can be looked down on or disliked for ignoring proper ETIQUETTE.

MANIPULATE.deftext:
to handle skillfully, manage, control

MANIPULATE comes from the Latin word for hand, also the source of the words manual and manufacture. To MANIPULATE something is to handle it, particularly with skill or cleverness.

“She MANIPULATED the controls expertly.”

In a general sense the word means to control or manage something or someone, particularly by artful or tricky means.

“The speaker knew how to MANIPULATE his audience so that they agreed with him.”

“I don’t mind being given advice, but I don’t like the idea that I’m being MANIPULATED to do what someone else wants.”

Other forms of the word: MANIPULATION, n.

questions.prompt: Do lion tamers have a PERILOUS job?
Is a PRELIMINARY decision the last one that will be made?
Would most people be NONCHALANT about winning a million dollars?
Does a reporter on television DENOUNCE the news?
Should you pay attention to someone who is in EARNEST?
Would an OPTIMIST worry a lot?
If someone climbed a mountain that had never been climbed before, would that be considered a CONQUEST?
Can you BEHOLD something that is in the distance?
Are secrets supposed to be DISCLOSED?
Is it usually considered proper ETIQUETTE to slam the door in someone's face?
Is it possible to MANIPULATE a hammer?
They all breathed a sigh of relief when they had completed the PERILOUS journey.
The wrestler SUBDUED his opponent with a trick hold.
The COMMERCIAL bank dealt mainly with the money needs of large businesses.
There will be a PRELIMINARY interview before we will let you formally apply for the job.
He ran at a BRISK pace through the park.
The angry teacher was NONCHALANT with everyone for disobeying.
The politician took every opportunity to issue public DENUNCIATIONS of his opponent.
I EARNESTLY recommend that you fix those stairs before someone gets hurt.
The coach was OPTIMISTIC about winning the title despite our injuries.
It was a close CONQUEST, but we finally lost.
His parents were very STERN. He wasn't allowed to do anything the other children did.
Traffic on the highway was BEHELD by a serious accident.
They asked for a full DISCLOSURE of what he knew about the business deal.
He knows nothing about ETIQUETTE: his table manners are disgraceful.
He is easily MANIPULATED: he will do anything if you ask him in the right way.

PRIMARILY.deftext:
chiefly, mainly, first of all

PRIMARILY comes from the Latin word for first. It is related to words like prime and primary. PRIMARILY means “in the first place,” mainly.

“He is PRIMARILY interested in making money.”

“We are here PRIMARILY to visit friends, but we will also see the sights if we have time.”

The most commonly marked incorrect answer on the Pretest is somewhat, which is not at all close in meaning to PRIMARILY.

Other forms of the word: PRIMARY, adj.

TESTY.deftext:
irritable, easily annoyed, cross, touchy

Someone who is TESTY gets easily annoyed when even small things go wrong.

“Jim gets very TESTY when things start to go wrong.”

“The teacher was quite TESTY this morning. She got angry at us no matter what we did.”

“He is usually very patient, but when people are late he starts to get TESTY.”

Many people think TESTY means curious, perhaps because one meaning of the verb TEST is to try out. A curious person would be willing to try out many different things. TESTY, however, is not related to this meaning of the word TEST.

Other forms of the word: TESTINESS,n.

CALAMITY.deftext:
a disaster, great misfortune, catastrophe

A CALAMITY is a major misfortune, like a plane crash or a crippling injury.

“The closing of the plant was a CALAMITY for the town, since suddenly no one had a job.”

“We were robbed, but it was no great CALAMITY. We just lost a few things.”

“The sudden death of Mr. Jones was quite a CALAMITY for the family.”

A common mistake is to choose problem as the meaning of CALAMITY. CALAMITY is much stronger than problem, however. The word should only be used about great disasters or misfortunes.

Other forms of the word: CALAMITOUS, adj.

STUPENDOUS.deftext:
amazing, awesome, astonishing

STUPENDOUS comes from a Latin word that means “to be astonished.” Something that is STUPENDOUS is so large or great that it leaves you speechless with amazement.

“The STUPENDOUS size of the Himalaya mountains is hard to believe.”

“He called the first trip to the moon one of man’s most STUPENDOUS accomplishments.”

“That earthquake was a STUPENDOUS disaster. Thousands of people died in it.”

The most popular wrong answer is interesting. STUPENDOUS is a much stronger word than interesting, though.

“Some movies are merely interesting. This movie was STUPENDOUS.”

VULNERABLE.deftext:
unprotected, exposed, open to attack

VULNERABLE comes from the Latin word for wound. Something that is VULNERABLE is able to be wounded; it is unprotected against damage or attack. See -able under Suffixes.

“Our army is VULNERABLE to an attack from the rear.”

“In this new armor only his eyes and hands are VULNERABLE.”

VULNERABLE can be used about more than just physical attack.

“Several people ran against our governor this year because they thought he was VULNERABLE and could be defeated.”

The most common mistake is to choose unbeatable as the meaning of VULNERABLE. This is confusing a word with its opposite. INVULNERABLE means “not able to be wounded.” See in-2 under Prefixes. Unbeatable would be synonymous with INVULNERABLE, but it is the opposite of VULNERABLE.

Other forms of the word: VULNERABILITY, n.

STRENUOUS.deftext:
energetic, active, vigorous

STRENUOUS means “using or requiring great effort,” vigorous. The word can be used about people or their activities.

“He was a STRENUOUS opponent of higher taxes.”

“The doctor advised him to avoid STRENUOUS exercise and to eat sensibly.”

“The students objected STRENUOUSLY to the plan to lengthen the school day.”

Many people confuse STRENUOUS with dangerous. STRENUOUS activities may sometimes be dangerous, but they do not have to be.

ENTAIL.deftext:
to involve, necessitate, impose, require

The original use of ENTAIL was in law. To ENTAIL property is to leave it in a will to particular people who cannot sell it or give it away. For example, a man might leave his house to his oldest child, who could only leave it to his oldest child, and so on. This was a way of ensuring that the property remained in the family.

If land is ENTAILED, this means that only certain things can be done with it, and certain people will automatically come into possession of it. From this, ENTAIL came generally to mean “to involve as a necessary result,” to require.

“This project will ENTAIL an enormous amount of work"-that is, a great deal of work will be necessary during the project.

“Freedom ENTAILS sacrifice"-that is, you cannot have one without the other.

VENGEANCE.deftext:
revenge

VENGEANCE is revenge, getting even for some insult or harm that has been done to you or your loved ones.

“He sought VENGEANCE against the person who had run over his dog.”

“He is so determined to get VENGEANCE for that insult that it’s impossible to reason with him.”

The person who is seeking VENGEANCE is VENGEFUL.

“The VENGEFUL man swore he wouldn’t rest until he’d found the person who had killed his wife.”

Other forms of the word: VENGEFUL, adj.

INTERVENE.deftext:
to come between, be between

See inter- under Prefixes. INTERVENE is used in several different senses, each of which basically means to come between. The word is used about events or actions which might occur in the course of something.

“We will go on as usual unless some problem INTERVENES.”

A person INTERVENES when he comes between other people in a quarrel or fight.

“It looked like the two of them were going to fight until the teacher INTERVENED.”

The word is used about time that passes between two events.

“Nothing much happened during the years that INTERVENED between his graduation and his marriage.”

Other forms of the word: INTERVENTION,n.

ELABORATE.deftext:
complicated, intricate, complex

ELABORATE is related to the word labor. Something which is ELABORATE has been worked out with great care and in great detail.

“She made ELABORATE plans for her wedding.”

“There were ELABORATE decorations on the cake.”

“He gave an ELABORATE explanation of why he was so late.”

ELABORATE is also a verb, pronounced i-lab’-:KAt. To ELABORATE or ELABORATE on something is to work it out or describe it in detail.

“We asked him to ELABORATE on his ideas about student government.”

Other forms of the word: ELABORATION,n.

DISTINCT.deftext:
separate; clear, plain

DISTINCT is related to the word distinguish. Something that is DISTINCT can clearly be seen as different from something else.

“His contribution to the project is quite DISTINCT from everyone else’s.”

“The two issues are DISTINCT: one is what we want to do, the other is what we can do.”

In a similar sense DISTINCT can be used about anything that is clear and unmistakable to the mind or senses.

“Although the background of the picture is blurred, his face is quite DISTINCT.”

“There is a DISTINCT difference between the Northern and Southern pronunciation of many words.”

“There is a DISTINCT smell of gas in the cellar. It isn’t a bad smell, but it’s very strong.”

REMOTE.deftext:
far away, far off, distant; slight

Something that is REMOTE is far away, either in space or time.

“He sailed to a REMOTE island in the middle of the ocean.”

“In the REMOTE past this area was all under water.”

“Their farm is REMOTE from any city or town.”

REMOTE can also mean small or slight.

“There is only a REMOTE possibility we will be there"-that is, there is a chance, but not a very good one.

“I haven’t the REMOTEST idea what you are talking about.”

Many people think REMOTE means unknown. Something that is far away, however, does not have to be unknown.

DINGY.deftext:
soiled, dirty, drab, shabby

DINGY means “having a dark, dirty appearance.” The word is used about things that have become soiled or faded through use or the passing of time.

“The sheets that were once so white are now gray and DINGY.”

“It was a dark, DINGY little room. Everything had a layer of dust on it.”

Old is often picked as meaning the same as DINGY. Something that is old, though, does not have to be DINGY.

OBSCURE.deftext:
unclear, hidden, vague

The basic meaning of OBSCURE is dark or hard to see.

“Their faces were OBSCURE in the dark room.”

OBSCURE has developed several slightly different uses from this basic meaning. The word can mean unclear, hard to understand.

“This poem is OBSCURE. I have no idea what the poet is trying to say.”

It can also mean little known.

“He was an OBSCURE artist who never achieved any success.”

“From OBSCURE beginnings he rose to become world famous.”

Or it can mean faint or indistinct.

“They heard OBSCURE sounds far in the distance.”

To OBSCURE something is to make it hard to see or understand.

“All the difficult words OBSCURED the meaning of the poem.”

Other forms of the word: OBSCURITY,n.

RIVALRY.deftext:
competition

RIVAL comes originally from a Latin word meaning stream. In Latin, a RIVAL was someone who lived on the opposite side of a stream and who had the right to use it along with you. Thus RIVALS are people who compete against each other because they want the same thing. RIVALRY is the state of being RIVALS.

“There was quite a RIVALRY between the two schools to see which would win the title.”

“Although their RIVALRY was intense, they still respected each other.”

“There was always RIVALRY among the brothers. Each one wanted to be the best in everything.”

Other forms of the word: RIVAL,n.,v.

questions.prompt: If someone is PRIMARILY interested in math, is that his favorite subject?
Do little children often get TESTY when they're overtired?
Would a plane crash be a CALAMITY?
If a person is VULNERABLE to attack, is he in danger?
Is climbing a mountain STRENUOUS exercise?
Does being a salesman ENTAIL meeting many people?
Would most people take VENGEANCE for a favor?
Is it possible to INTERVENE in an argument?
Is a meal of bread and water ELABORATE?
Is Canada REMOTE from the United States?
Would a freshly washed shirt usually be DINGY?
Is there usually a RIVALRY among the people who want to be president?
He was PRIMARILY an actor, but he could also sing and dance quite well.
Al was TESTY about how long the corridor was, so he measured it himself.
No one else minded much, but Bob thought it was a CALAMITY when lunch was a few minutes late.
Hal thought the book was good, but not really STUPENDOUS.
The city was so VULNERABLE that no one could ever conquer it.
These wires are quite STRENUOUS. Touch one and you will die instantly.
Getting high marks in school usually ENTAILS a great deal of studying.
Her VENGEANCE for the murder of her child was both swift and terrifying.
He INTERVENED her to come with him to the party.
In her speech she ELABORATED on some of the points I had made in mine.
Bill had the DISTINCT feeling that he was being followed.
The doctor was only REMOTELY concerned about the danger of getting any diseases from his patients.
It was such a DINGY amount of money that we didn't care about it.
I felt OBSCURE about it until someone showed me what to do.
He had several RIVALS in the swimming competition, but he was able to beat them all.

CONDEMN.deftext:
to blame, criticize; to sentence, doom

To CONDEMN something is to declare that it is wrong or evil. CONDEMN is a very strong word and suggests complete disapproval.

“We all CONDEMNED his cruel treatment of the students.”

“She CONDEMNED the governor for his stand on taxes.”

To CONDEMN someone to something is to doom or sentence him to it.

“The judge CONDEMNED him to death.”

“His illness CONDEMNED him to a life spent in a wheelchair.”

The most common mistake in the Pretest is to choose dislike as the meaning of CONDEMN. CONDEMN is much stronger than dislike, however. You can dislike someone but not CONDEMN him.

Other forms of the word: CONDEMNATION, n.

ENTERPRISE.deftext:
an undertaking, project; a business, company; energy, daring, spirit

An ENTERPRISE is a project or undertaking, especially one that is risky or requires a great deal of skill or courage.

“Climbing MountbEverest is quite an ENTERPRISE.”

“Getting him up in the morning was a difficult ENTERPRISE.”

ENTERPRISE is also used for the spirit or energy which someone has to have to accomplish a challenging project.

“It took men of great ENTERPRISE to explore this jungle.”

ENTERPRISE is also another word for business or company.

“He owned a small but growing ENTERPRISE.”

“Free ENTERPRISE” is an economic system in which business projects can be undertaken with little restriction by the government.

Other forms of the word: ENTERPRISING, adj.

MURAL.deftext:
a wall painting

A MURAL is a painting done directly on a wall. The word MURAL comes from the Latin word for wall. MURALS can also be large photographs or wallpaper scenes which are attached right to the wall, without a frame.

"The Last Supper is a MURAL painted by Leonardo da Vinci.”

“The artist painted a colorful MURAL in the subway station.”

REMNANT.deftext:
a remainder, part left over

REMNANT is related to the word remain. A REMNANT is a part left over, usually a very small or insignificant part.

“This painting is the only REMNANT of a once-huge art collection.”

“The enemy quickly captured the REMNANTS of the defeated army.”

“After the town burned down, people searched through the REMNANTS looking for survivors.”

A specific use of REMNANT is for a small piece of cloth left over after the larger part has been sold.

“The fabric store sold the REMNANTS at a greatly reduced price.”

CORONATION.deftext:
the act of crowning

Corona is the Latin word for crown. A CORONATION is a crowning of a king, queen, or other ruler, with all the ceremonies that are part of the event.

“Many heads of state attended the CORONATION of the new king.”

“At Napoleon’s CORONATION he took the crown and placed it on his head himself.”

The most common wrong answer on the Pretest is celebration. There may be celebrations along with a CORONATION, but CORONATION has to do specifically with the crowning of a ruler.

EMPLOY.deftext:
to use, make use of; to give work to

To EMPLOY something is to make use of it.

“He EMPLOYED every trick he knew, but he still couldn’t beat his opponent.”

“The grounds crew EMPLOYED a large helicopter to help dry off the field.”

To EMPLOY a person is to make use of his services, usually for pay.

“This factory EMPLOYS thousands of workers.”

“Bill is EMPLOYED by the insurance company to investigate accident claims.”

An EMPLOYER is a person or company who hires a worker, and an EMPLOYEE is a person who works for a company.

Other forms of the word: EMPLOYEE, n. EMPLOYER, n. EMPLOYMENT, n.

GALA.deftext:
festive, showy

GALA is both an adjective and a noun. As a noun it means “a special entertainment,” a celebration.

“All the leading society figures came to the GALA celebrating the opening of the museum.”

As an adjective the word means “like a GALA or celebration,” festive.

“His parties were always GALA occasions. Everyone loved to go to them.”

“It was a GALA day from beginning to end, with parades, games, plays, and all kinds of festivities.”

OOZE.deftext:
to flow slowly, leak out

OOZE is the soft liquid mud at the bottom of a river or other body of water. To OOZE is to flow slowly like this mud, especially through small openings.

“Oil OOZED out of the crack in the engine.”

“Blood OOZED from the wound.”

OOZE can also mean to give off.

“His faced OOZED sweat as he tried to lift the trunk.”

The word can be used in a general sense about things and qualities besides liquids.

“She OOZED self-confidence as she strode into the room"-that is, she had so much self-confidence that it seemed to flow out of her.

Many people think OOZE means to overflow. Both words are used about the flow of liquids, but OOZE means to flow out slowly.

ORATION.deftext:
a formal speech

An ORATION is a formal, dignified speech made on a public occasion.

“Marc Antony delivered a great ORATION at Caesar’s funeral.”

“The politician’s ORATION put most of the audience to sleep.”

An ORATOR is a person who makes such speeches.

“Daniel Webster was a great ORATOR. People would travel hundreds of miles to hear one of his speeches.”

Other forms of the word: ORATOR, n. ORATORY, n.

SATANIC.deftext:
devilish, wicked, evil

SATANIC is the adjective formed from SATAN, one of several names for the devil. See -ic under Suffixes. SATANIC means wicked or evil, like the devil.

“His SATANIC smile frightened everyone there.”

“Sometimes a truly SATANIC nature is hidden behind a mask of good manners.”

Crazy is the most commonly chosen wrong answer on the Pretest, perhaps because SATANIC sounds a little like moronic.

MULTITUDE.deftext:
a crowd, a great number

See -tude under Suffixes. MULTITUDE comes from a Latin word meaning many, also the source of the word multiply. A MULTITUDE is a great number of something.

“This wonderful machine can do a MULTITUDE of jobs all at once.”

“There was a MULTITUDE of complaints about the new system of report cards.”

When used by itself, the word usually means “a great crowd of people.”

“A MULTITUDE had gathered to hear the president’s speech.”

SHUN.deftext:
to avoid, stay away from

SHUN means to avoid or stay away from something, usually because it is hateful, undesirable, or dangerous. You can SHUN both people and things.

“His friends SHUNNED him after they learned about his evil past.” “She SHUNS work whenever she can.”

“A hermit SHUNS the company of other people.”

AGENDA.deftext:
an outline, program

An AGENDA is a list or outline of things to be done, a plan of procedure. Often a committee will organize its meetings around an AGENDA of subjects to be discussed or business to be carried out.

“The chairman made sure that every committee member received an AGENDA before each meeting.”

“The next item on the AGENDA is a discussion of how the money is to be spent.”

“My father called and wanted to know what was on our AGENDA for this weekend"-that is, he wanted to know what we were planning to do.

MATERNAL.deftext:
motherly

Mater means mother in Latin. MATERNAL means “of or like a mother.” See -al under Suffixes.

“She has MATERNAL feelings for her students. She treats them all like her children.”

“Her MATERNAL instincts told her that her children were in trouble.”

MATERNAL also means “on your mother’s side of the family.” Your MATERNAL grandfather is your mother’s father.

STREW.deftext:
to spread, scatter, sprinkle

To STREW something is to spread it here and there over a surface.

“She STREWED the birdseed on the ground for the pigeons.”

STREW also means “to cover a surface with scattered things.”

“Pebbles STREW the surface of the road.”

The form STREWN is often used for what is called the past participle of STREW.

“The floor was STREWN with books and papers.”

“The child’s toys were STREWN over the room.”

COMPOUND.deftext:
a combination, mixture

A COMPOUND is something formed by combining different parts or ingredients. See con- under Prefixes.

“Water is a COMPOUND of oxygen and hydrogen.”

“His book is a COMPOUND of interesting facts and silly theories.”

COMPOUND words, such as storeroom and outside, are words that are made up of other words.

COMPOUND is also a verb, meaning “to make a mixture.” The verb form of the word is pronounced (kÔøΩm- pownd)’.

“The druggist COMPOUNDED the medicine out of several others.”

The verb also means simply to add to, increase.

“Our latest attempt at a solution simply COMPOUNDED our problems.”

APPOINT.deftext:
to name, designate

To APPOINT someone is to name him to a job or a position.

“The president APPOINTED him to be his personal secretary.”

“Jim was APPOINTED class treasurer by the teacher.”

To APPOINT is also to fix or choose a time for an event.

“We were all there at the APPOINTED time, ready to begin work.”

An APPOINTMENT is the act of APPOINTING.

“He opposed the APPOINTMENT of that judge to the Supreme Court.”

It is especially used to mean “an agreed-upon arrangement for a meeting.”

“They had an APPOINTMENT to eat lunch together on Thursday.”

Other forms of the word: APPOINTMENT, n.

COMPENSATE.deftext:
to make up, offset, balance; to pay, pay back

To COMPENSATE for something is to make up for it.

“She COMPENSATED for being unable to use her legs by getting a special car with hand controls.”

“You can’t COMPENSATE for weeks of not studying by staying up and reading all night just before the exam.”

Very often COMPENSATE refers to money which is used to make up for loss or injury.

“The company paid Sam a thousand dollars to COMPENSATE him for the injury he suffered at work.”

The noun form of COMPENSATE is COMPENSATION, which is something given, usually money, to make up for something else.

“She had to sue to get the COMPENSATION due her for the accident.”

“He receives adequate COMPENSATION for the work he does.”

Other forms of the word: COMPENSATION, n.

DUMBFOUNDED.deftext:
amazed, astonished, puzzled

The word DUMB has two meanings. The first is “not able to speak,” speechless, as in the phrase “deaf and DUMB.” The second is stupid, dull. DUMBFOUNDED comes from the first meaning. To be DUMBFOUNDED is to be so surprised and puzzled that you are speechless.

“We were DUMBFOUNDED when we discovered that the treasure was missing.”

“The DUMBFOUNDED explorers could only stare in wonder at the palace they had discovered in the middle of the jungle.”

The most common mistake on the Pretest is the choice of stupid as the meaning of DUMBFOUNDED-due to confusion, of course, with the second meaning of DUMB.

Other forms of the word: DUMBFOUND, v.

Usage: DUMBFOUNDED is also often spelled dumfounded.

ELEVATING.deftext:
uplifting, exalting

To ELEVATE something is to lift it up higher. The adjective ELEVATING means “tending to lift up minds or morals.” The word is almost never used about something that is physically being lifted.

“The minister gave a very ELEVATING sermon which left everyone determined to lead better lives.”

“Alice said her visit to the art museum had been an ELEVATING experience.”

Other forms of the word: ELEVATE,v.

ACKNOWLEDGE.deftext:
to admit, confess; to recognize, accept

You can see the word knowledge in ACKNOWLEDGE. ACKNOWLEDGE has two rather different uses that deal with knowledge. First, to ACKNOWLEDGE something is to admit you have knowledge of it, to state or agree that it exists or has happened.

“By signing the form, he ACKNOWLEDGED receipt of the package from the post office.”

“The criminal ACKNOWLEDGED his guilt and begged for another chance.”

Second, to ACKNOWLEDGE can mean to take notice of. Often the word is used about a gift or letter, to show that you have received it.

“She sent them a short note ACKNOWLEDGING their present and thanking them for their thoughtfulness.”

ACKNOWLEDGE in this sense can also be used about responsibilities or duties to show that you recognize and accept them.

“Bill ACKNOWLEDGED his obligation to help the poor in any way he could.”

Other forms of the word: ACKNOWLEDGMENT, n.

CLARITY.deftext:
clearness, distinctness

CLARITY is the quality of being clear. The word can be used about things that are clear to the eye or clear to the mind.

“The water was of such CLARITY that you could see all the way to the bottom of the lake.”

“The photograph lacked CLARITY. We couldn’t make out any of the faces.”

“He presented his arguments with great CLARITY. Everyone could follow him quite easily.”

CONDENSE.deftext:
to shorten, compress, abridge

CONDENSE is related to the word dense, which means “packed tightly together.” When something CONDENSES,it occupies less space,it becomes denser or more compact. The word is used about gases which turn into liquids.

“The steam CONDENSED to water when it reached the cold window.”

CONDENSE is also used about written material or other kinds of information. To CONDENSE it is to make it shorter, to abridge it.

“We don’t have time to hear that long report. Could you CONDENSE it into a few sentences?”

“They had to CONDENSE twenty hours of film into a half-hour television show.”

Other forms of the word: CONDENSATION, n.

IMPARTIAL.deftext:
fair, unbiased, just

See in-2 under Prefixes. One meaning of partial is “favoring one person or side more than the other.”

“He admitted that he was partial to people with a sense of humor.”

Someone who is IMPARTIAL shows no favoritism, is strictly fair and unprejudiced.

“We want an IMPARTIAL jury. We don’t want people who have made up their minds ahead of time.”

“They couldn’t agree among themselves, so they brought the problem to an IMPARTIAL outsider and let him decide.”

“It’s hard to be IMPARTIAL when you know someone who’s involved in the case.”

Other forms of the word: IMPARTIALITY,n.

CONTRARY.deftext:
opposite, opposed; stubborn, self-willed

Something that is CONTRARY to something else is opposed to it, is the total opposite of it.

“You may think he is kind, but I have heard a CONTRARY opinion from someone else.”

“CONTRARY to what you might have expected, I passed the course quite easily.”

“The two candidates held CONTRARY views on many issues.”

CONTRARY can also be used about a person who is very self-willed and is always doing or saying the opposite of what people want or suggest.

“She’s a CONTRARY child. We can never get her to obey.”

In this sense, the word is often pronounced (kÔøΩn-trair’-E).

BARREN.deftext:
empty, fruitless

BARREN has several uses, all of which have the idea of empty, fruitless, or unproductive. Land which is BARREN is no good for growing crops; it is unproductive. BARREN land is also often very difficult for people or animals to survive in, because it is too cold or windy or desert-like. BARREN trees or plants do not produce fruit or seeds. BARREN discussions have no results; they are empty and worthless.

“We had several BARREN conversations about the matter; we never came to any conclusion about what should be done.”

COMRADE.deftext:
a friend, companion

A COMRADE is a friend or companion, someone who is loyal to you and whom you see often.

“They became friends when they were in the fifth grade and remained COMRADES for life.”

“She was my COMRADE in school. We went everywhere together; we were almost never apart.”

“His trusted COMRADE turned against him and betrayed him.”

COMRADE is a usual form of address used by Communists.

“COMRADE Ustinov will give a speech at the next meeting of the Communist party.”

This may lead many people to choose enemy or leader as a synonym for COMRADE.

BARTER.deftext:
to trade, exchange

When you BARTER you trade goods or services for what you want instead of using money.

“In ‘Jack and the Beanstalk,’ Jack BARTERED the family’s cow for a handful of beans. His mother thought it was a bad trade.”

“The farmer BARTERED the use of his tractor in exchange for part of the crop.”

BARTER is also a noun meaning a trade or exchange.

“The doctor decided that having his cellar cleaned was a good BARTER for fixing Dan’s broken arm.”

COINCIDE.deftext:
to agree, be the same, correspond; to happen at the same time

When two things COINCIDE, they are in agreement or in harmony with one another. In this sense, COINCIDE is generally used about opinions, wishes, judgments, or the like.

“Your views on politics COINCIDE completely with my own.”

“The teacher’s opinion of the boy did not COINCIDE with his parents’ opinion of him.”

COINCIDE also means “to happen at the same time.”

“His arrival at the airport COINCIDED with a strike by the pilots.”

“Her birthday and mine COINCIDE.”

A COINCIDENCE is a chance occurrence of two events at the same time.

“It was a strange COINCIDENCE that the two old friends should both be in the foreign city on business.”

Other forms of the word: COINCIDENCE, n.

COURIER.deftext:
a messenger

COURIER comes from a French word which means to run. A COURIER is someone who carries messages or information. A COURIER doesn’t necessarily run, but the word often suggests speed and urgency.

“The general sent a COURIER ahead to tell the fort that more troops were on their way.”

“The COURIER arrived at the palace with the secret papers.”

“Each morning the COURIER brought them reports on the military situation.”

The school CONDENSED the six-month course so that now it takes a year.
We became very IMPARTIAL for him to arrive after we had been waiting for two hours.
The boy is so CONTRARY that he won't do anything the teacher asks him to do.
His efforts were completely BARREN; he had nothing to show for his work.
They were my COMRADES in the army; now I never see them any more.
He thought that getting a car in exchange for a few old chairs was a good BARTER.
The two cars arrived at the corner at the same time and COINCIDED with a loud crash.
The COURIER had to slip through enemy territory to bring the news to headquarters.

TIMID.deftext:
fearful, easily frightened, shy

TIMID means fearful, easily frightened, easily alarmed.

“He became very TIMID about riding in elevators after he was stuck in one once.”

“She looks TIMID, but she can really be quite brave when she needs to be.”

TIMID often adds to fearful the idea of shyness.

“He greeted his grandfather with a TIMID smile.”

“She is very TIMID at large parties.”

Other forms of the word: TIMIDITY, n.

SPLINTER.deftext:
to break up, split into pieces, break off

A SPLINTER is a little piece of something, usually wood.

“You’re apt to get SPLINTERS in your fingers when you’re working with wood.”

SPLINTER, when used as a verb, means “to break into very small pieces.”

“The wall SPLINTERED with just one blow from the heavy hammer.”

“The icicles SPLINTERED when they hit the ground.”

“He could SPLINTER a board with his bare hand.”

PROVERB.deftext:
a saying, maxim, adage

A PROVERB is a short saying that uses simple, vivid language to express some ancient wisdom. Some examples of PROVERBS are “Look before you leap,” “A rolling stone gathers no moss,” and “Still waters run deep.”

Something that is so well known that it has become a PROVERB is called PROVERBIAL.

“She talked about the PROVERBIAL curiosity of a cat.”

The most common mistake for the meaning of PROVERB on the Pretest is story. A PROVERB is never more than a sentence or two long. It does not tell a story, but gives some general truth.

Other forms of the word: PROVERBIAL, adj.

REVISE.deftext:
to change, correct

REVISE basically means “to look back at.” See re- under Prefixes. The vise part of the word is related to words like vision. To REVISE something is to look it over or reexamine it and make changes and corrections.

“He REVISED his composition so that it made better sense.”

“The new figures caused them to REVISE their estimate of how much the job would cost.”

“When he started being nice to everyone we had to REVISE our bad opinion of him.”

Other forms of the word: REVISION, n.

INFECTIOUS.deftext:
catching, contagious

To INFECT someone is to contaminate him with disease-producing germs.

“Mosquitoes INFECTED the natives with malaria.”

“The wound became INFECTED when he didn’t keep it clean.”

INFECTIOUS is an adjective from INFECT. See -ous under Suffixes. An INFECTIOUS disease is one that spreads by INFECTING, like the flu or smallpox. INFECTIOUS is also used in a general way and means “spreading quickly,” catching.

“Yawning is INFECTIOUS. Once one person starts, everyone begins to do it.”

“He had an INFECTIOUS laugh that caused everyone to laugh with him.”

Deadly is the most commonly chosen incorrect answer on the Pretest. INFECTIOUS diseases are communicated by germs. Some of these diseases are deadly, others are not.

Other forms of the word: INFECT, v. INFECTION, n.

POPULACE.deftext:
the common people, the general public

POPULACE comes from the Latin word for people, also the source of the words population and popular. The POPULACE is the common people, as opposed to the wealthy or the noble.

“The politician’s plan appealed to the POPULACE, although big business was against it.”

“Although the king now had less power, the POPULACE still did not like him.”

POPULACE is also used for the entire population of a place.

“It seemed as if the whole POPULACE of the town had turned out to greet him.”

MONUMENTAL.deftext:
immense, massive, imposing

A MONUMENT is a large building, statue, or other object which serves to keep alive the memory of a person or event.

“The Washington MONUMENT is a great tribute to our first president.”

MONUMENTAL means “having the size and impressiveness of a MONUMENT,” massive, immense. See -al under Suffixes.

“It was a MONUMENTAL structure, almost a hundred stories high.”

“They made a mistake of MONUMENTAL proportions. They almost ruined the entire project.”

“Building the Panama Canal was a MONUMENTAL achievement.”

Other forms of the word: MONUMENT, n.

PONDER.deftext:
to consider, reflect, meditate, deliberate

PONDER comes from a Latin word meaning to weigh. PONDER means “to weigh carefully in the mind.”

“He PONDERED the decision for a long time before acting.”

“Sally PONDERED whether to save her money or buy a new dress.”

PONDER is sometimes followed by over or on, in which case it means to think deeply, to meditate.

“She PONDERED over the mysteries of life.”

“He PONDERED on the importance of planning ahead.”

SCORN.deftext:
to despise, feel contempt for; refuse SCORN is both a verb and a noun. To SCORN something is to despise it, to treat it or consider it with contempt.

“Everyone SCORNED him for his laziness.”

You can also SCORN something and refuse to do it because it is worthless or beneath you.

“Although she needs the money, she SCORNS offers of jobs as a cleaning person.”

When SCORN is used as a noun, it means “a feeling of contempt.”

“She has a great deal of SCORN for people who lie about their ages.”

Other forms of the word: SCORNFUL, adj.

REIMBURSE.deftext:
to pay back, repay

See re- and in-1 under Prefixes. The burse part of the word is related to the word purse. The basic meaning of the word is “to put back into someone’s purse,” that is, to repay someone. Usually the word is used about paying money to a person who has already had to spend some of his own.

“The company REIMBURSED him for the money he spent on the trip.”

“We will gladly REIMBURSE you for the cost of the phone calls.”

“He bought the plane ticket himself, expecting to be REIMBURSED later.”

The most commonly chosen incorrect answer on the Pretest is back up. This is probably chosen because REIMBURSE sounds like reinforce.

OBSTINATE.deftext:
stubborn, unyielding

OBSTINATE people do not yield to another’s arguments or persuasion. They hold fast to their own ideas or plans. The word often suggests that OBSTINATE people are being unreasonable in not changing their minds or listening to others.

“The OBSTINATE mule wouldn’t move until its master fed him.”

“He OBSTINATELY refused to see a doctor until it was too late.”

Something that is OBSTINATE is not easily overcome or removed.

“Their OBSTINATE resistance to change finally forced them to go out of business.”

“His illness was quite OBSTINATE; despite all the treatment he still didn’t get better.”

Other forms of the word: OBSTINACY, n.

VELOCITY.deftext:
speed, quickness

VELOCITY is the speed of something along a given path.

“The car traveled at a VELOCITY of fifty miles an hour.”

“They had an instrument which measured the VELOCITY of a baseball thrown by a pitcher.”

“The wind is blowing in an easterly direction at a VELOCITY of 25 miles per hour.”

PERPLEX.deftext:
to confuse, bewilder, puzzle

To PERPLEX someone is to confuse and puzzle him. The word usually suggests a problem that worries and frustrates a person.

“The teacher’s questions PERPLEXED him until he suddenly hit upon the answer.”

“We have several PERPLEXING problems that we must somehow solve.”

“I’m PERPLEXED by your attitude. I just don’t understand why you’re acting this way.”

PERPLEXED is also an adjective.

“The PERPLEXED young man didn’t know which way to turn for help.”

PERPLEXITY is the state of being PERPLEXED.

“He admitted his PERPLEXITY at the strange way she was behaving.”

Other forms of the word: PERPLEXITY, n.

PEDIGREE.deftext:
ancestry, family descent

A PEDIGREE is the ancestry of a person or animal, or a record of that ancestry. The word usually suggests a noble or distinguished family tree. The word is especially used in reference to animals, where it stresses proof of pure breeding for many generations.

“She insisted that any dog she bought should have a PEDIGREE.”

“They were very proud of their family’s long PEDIGREE.”

INFORMAL.deftext:
not formal, unofficial

See in-2 under Prefixes. FORMAL means “following the rules or customs.” Something which is INFORMAL is done without ceremony or great attention to the rules.

“They held some INFORMAL discussions before starting the official meeting.”

“There was an INFORMAL investigation into the cause of the fire, but no report was ever written.”

“He gave a brief, INFORMAL talk about his trip to Europe.”

Many people think INFORMAL means unimportant. An INFORMAL meeting or discussion could, however, be quite important.

Other forms of the word: INFORMALITY, n.

questions.prompt: Are most people part of the POPULACE?
Would a MONUMENTAL mistake be easy to fix?

Does using the brake of a car increase its VELOCITY?
