We used tweezers to get the SPLINTERS out of his knee.
He said that this latest problem was the PROVERBIAL straw that broke the camel's back.
His INFECTIOUS enthusiasm made everyone want to try harder.
The president could not convince the POPULACE that they should pay higher taxes.
He REVISED us again that we would be in trouble if we didn't agree.
He claimed his invention was of MONUMENTAL importance.
She PONDERED why he could be acting so strangely.
The coach feels nothing but SCORN for players who don't try as hard as they can.
We offered to REIMBURSE him, but he said he had spent too little money for us to worry about it.
The lock proved to be quite OBSTINATE, so finally we had to break the door down.
The arrows hit the target at different times because each had a different VELOCITY.
She PERPLEXED us to stop talking during class.
Since the dog had no PEDIGREE, we decided not to buy him.
The president met INFORMALLY with the two reporters this morning, but his official news conference isn't until this afternoon.

CREDIBLE.deftext:
believable, trustworthy

See -able under Suffixes. The cred part of the word comes from the Latin word for believe. Something which is CREDIBLE is able to be believed.

“His explanation of why he was late was CREDIBLE.”

“His story about being captured by Martians was not very CREDIBLE.”

Someone who is CREDIBLE is trustworthy and can be believed.

“A CREDIBLE witness says she saw him somewhere else, so I guess he didn’t commit the crime.”

Many people select true as the meaning of CREDIBLE on the Pretest. Something that is CREDIBLE will usually be true, but does not have to be.

“The story was CREDIBLE, so newspapers printed it; we then found out it was a practical joke.”

Other forms of the word: CREDIBILITY, n.

LEGITIMATE.deftext:
lawful; reasonable, proper, valid

LEGITIMATE comes from the Latin word for law, also the source of the word legal. The basic meaning of LEGITIMATE is lawful.

“The court decided his claim was LEGITIMATE.”

The word is now also used rather broadly to mean reasonable, logical, justifiable.

“He has a LEGITIMATE excuse for being absent"- that is, his excuse makes sense, it is justified.

“This money should only be used for LEGITIMATE purposes.”

“He had a LEGITIMATE reason to be upset with us.”

UNEARTH.deftext:
to discover, uncover, find

See un- under Prefixes. UNEARTH basically means “to take the earth covering off something.” In general use, UNEARTH means to uncover or discover something.

“The researcher UNEARTHED some new information about George Washington’s career in the army.”

“When tracing your family’s history, you may UNEARTH embarrassing things about your ancestors.”

“He UNEARTHED a plot to kill the judge.”

UNFURL.deftext:
to open out, unroll, spread out

UNFURL is used chiefly with flags, sails, and other large pieces of fabric. When you FURL a flag or sail, you roll it up. So to UNFURL a flag is to open it out or to spread it out. See un- under Prefixes.

“For the holiday, all the flags were UNFURLED.”

“In preparation for the journey, all the sails on the ship were UNFURLED and inspected for damage.”

Other forms of the word: FURL, v.

PRIM.deftext:
neat, tidy, stiffly formal

A PRIM person is overly neat in his appearance and overly proper in his behavior. The word usually suggests someone who dislikes anything rough or vulgar. It often suggests that this is a bad quality, that the person is too concerned about his appearance and too worried about improper behavior.

“The PRIM old lady was shocked by our ragged appearance.”

“The PRIM gentleman never went out of the house without being perfectly dressed.”

“She PRIMLY informed us that little boys were not allowed to sit on her nice clean chairs.”

HABITUAL.deftext:
regular, usual, customary

A HABIT is a fixed way of doing something.

“He had a bad HABIT of talking with his mouth full.”

Something which is HABITUAL results from HABIT, is usual or regular. See -al under Suffixes.

“He took his HABITUAL walk after dinner.”

“She drank her HABITUAL cup of coffee in the middle of the morning.”

HABITUAL is also used about people, and means “acting by HABIT.”

“Don’t believe him; he’s a HABITUAL liar.”

“She’s a HABITUAL latecomer; she never gets anywhere on time.”

Other forms of the word: HABIT, n.

PUTRID.deftext:
rotten, decayed, very distasteful - Something that is PUTRID is in an advanced state of decay, so that it has a foul taste and smell. Food which is PUTRID is disgusting and distasteful.

“They refused to eat the fish because of its PUTRID smell.”

“The meat had been left outside in the sun and turned PUTRID.”

Often PUTRID is simply used to mean awful, terrible, vile.

“Ed said the movie was PUTRID-one of the worst he had ever seen.”

PAGEANTRY.deftext:
grand display, splendid spectacle

A PAGEANT is a public show or spectacle, often involving colorful floats and costumes. PAGEANTRY is the colorful, splendid display of a PAGEANT.

“The crowning of a new king is always full of PAGEANTRY.”

PAGEANTRY is sometimes used in a bad sense, to suggest that there is nothing important beneath all the display and spectacle.

“The play had plenty of PAGEANTRY but little else.”

Other forms of the word: PAGEANT, n.

HERALD.deftext:
to announce, proclaim, give notice of

A HERALD was a person who made public announcements for a king. From this the word has come to be used about any person or thing that announces or signals something that is to come.

“The clear sky in the distance was a HERALD of better weather in a few hours.”

To HERALD something, therefore, is to give public notice that it is going to happen, to announce it. You can HERALD something in other ways besides speaking.

“Thousands of posters throughout the town HERALDED the candidate’s arrival.”

“The appearance of the first robin HERALDED the arrival of spring.”

ENDORSE.deftext:
to approve, support, vouch for, uphold

The dorse part of the word comes from a Latin word for back; the word’s basic meaning is “to write on the back of” something, particularly an official document or a business document. To ENDORSE a check is to write your name on the back of it in order to cash it.

A common reason for ENDORSING a document was to indicate your approval of what was on the other side. This led to the general use of ENDORSE as a word meaning to approve or support.

“We ENDORSE your position on taxes.”

“Whom did they ENDORSE for president?”

The sense of the word is that if you ENDORSE something, you would be willing to sign a statement that you approve of it.

Other forms of the word: ENDORSEMENT, n.

UPRISING.deftext:
a rebellion, revolt

UPRISING is made up of the words rising and up. An UPRISING is the rising up of people in a rebellion against their government. The word is often used about small, ineffective rebellions and also about the beginnings of widespread revolts.

“In the last five hundred years there have been several UPRISINGS of the Irish against English rule.”

“The UPRISING against the government was quickly put down by the army.”

“His kingdom was never totally peaceful; a small UPRISING was always taking place in one part or another.”

In the Pretest, many people select riot as the meaning of UPRISING. The two words are close in meaning. A riot is any kind of public disorder by a group of people; an UPRISING is specifically aimed against the government or those in power.

PROMINENT.deftext:
easily seen, standing out; well-known, notable, distinguished

The basic meaning of PROMINENT is standing out, so as to be easily seen. See pro- under Prefixes.

“The huge mountain is a PROMINENT landmark in the area.”

“She has very PROMINENT cheekbones.”

When used about people, the word means well-known, important, usually in a good sense.

“He is one of the most PROMINENT citizens of this community.”

“The town was shocked when two PROMINENT doctors were charged with murder.”

“She played a PROMINENT part in producing the show.”

Other forms of the word: PROMINENCE, n.

MIMIC.deftext:
to copy, imitate

To MIMIC someone is to copy his speech or movements, often with the intention of making fun of him. The word usually suggests a very exact copying.

“Sally MIMICKED the odd way her sister talked.”

“The skillful actor could MIMIC any kind of character he chose.”

A MIMIC is a person who MIMICS.

“The clever MIMIC spoke and acted just like the famous politician.”

Many people think that to MIMIC someone is to laugh at him, probably because MIMICKING often involves making fun of the person who is being MIMICKED.

LUNACY.deftext:
insanity, madness

LUNACY is from luna, the Latin word for the moon. It used to be thought that madness was related to the changes of the moon. Thus, LUNACY is another word for madness, particularly spells of madness that come and go.

“It was an act of LUNACY to go walking in the snowstorm without any clothes on.”

“Usually he was quite reasonable, but he had moments of utter LUNACY.”

A LUNATIC is a crazy person, someone affected by LUNACY.

“Only a LUNATIC would burn down his own house.”

Other forms of the word: LUNATIC, n.

ACCESSIBLE.deftext:
approachable, easy to reach

Anything you can reach, use, or visit is ACCESSIBLE. ACCESSIBLE usually suggests that it is not too difficult to get to the person or place it refers to.

“This store is easily ACCESSIBLE to people coming by car or bus.”

“The boss was always ACCESSIBLE and ready to listen to complaints or new ideas.”

“We are lucky to have the library so ACCESSIBLE to us; we don’t have to walk far to exchange our books.”

The opposite of ACCESSIBLE is INACCESSIBLE, which means “out of reach.”

“The librarian told her that the books were INACCESSIBLE because they were being recovered.”

Other forms of the word: ACCESS, n. INACCESSIBLE, adj.

The contest isn't LEGITIMATE: the winners have been picked already.
It took several years to UNEARTH the cause of the strange disease.
The ship set out with all her sails UNFURLED and billowing in the breeze.
He's so PRIM and proper he'd think that wrestling in the mud was the most disgusting thing in the world.
As usual he performed his HABITUAL morning exercises.
Meat will turn PUTRID if not cooked or frozen.
After a while he became bored by all the PAGEANTRY and longed for something simpler.
The development of the polio vaccine HERALDED the conquest of that terrible disease.
The mayor ENDORSED the police department's efforts to reduce crime.
The government is just too strong; an UPRISING against it would have no chance of success.
He was a PROMINENT person, always saying he would do something and never getting around to it.
He liked to MIMIC the unusual way the teacher walked.
We placed all our medicines in a place that was INACCESSIBLE to the baby.

ASCEND.deftext:
to go up, rise, climb

ASCEND means simply to go up.

“The elevator ASCENDED to the top floor.”

“They threw bags of sand out of the balloon to make it ASCEND.”

“The soldier ASCENDED through the ranks until he became a general.”

Many people confuse ASCEND with its opposite descend, which means to go down.

“They ASCENDED the mountain in the morning, and descended it in the afternoon.”

Other forms of the word: ASCENT, n.

OUTLANDISH.deftext:
strange, bizarre, ridiculous

See -ish under Suffixes. OUTLAND is a rare word for a foreign land or country-a land that is outside your own. Something that it OUTLANDISH has a foreign or unfamiliar appearance or quality. It is strange, bizarre, exotic.

“She dressed in OUTLANDISH clothing just to shock people.”

“He had some OUTLANDISH ideas about flying saucers.”

“They made some OUTLANDISH suggestions about how to improve television.”

UNCANNY.deftext:
weird, strange, mysterious

UNCANNY means weird or strange. The word is applied to people, events, or feelings that are so beyond what is normal or expected that they make you feel frightened or uncomfortable.

“He has an UNCANNY way of knowing what you’re thinking.”

“That dog is so smart it’s almost UNCANNY.”

“We were frightened by the UNCANNY sounds.”

VIVID.deftext:
lively, spirited, intense

VIVID comes from a Latin word meaning to live, also the source of English words like survive and revive. VIVID means “full of life and freshness.” The word is used about things, as well as about ideas, memories, imaginations, and the like.

“The picture is painted in sharp, VIVID colors that make a strong impression on the eye.”

“After all these years her memories of her trip to Europe are still fresh and VIVID.”

“The author wrote a VIVID account of the battle. You almost felt as if you were there.”

“Little Billy has a VIVID imagination. He’s always pretending to be a detective or an astronaut.”

NULLIFY.deftext:
to make void, invalidate, negate See -fy under Suffixes. The NULL part of the word means nothing. NULL is an adjective which means “without value or effect.” It is often used in the phrase “NULL and void,” which means “having no legal force.”

“The judges declared that the agreement was NULL and void.”

To NULLIFY something is to make it as if it were nothing, to take away its force, value, or usefulness.

“The referee’s decision NULLIFIED the touchdown.”

“His refusal to let us finish NULLIFIED all our work for the past month. It’s as if we’d never even begun.”

Other forms of the word: NULL, adj. NULLIFICATION, n.

INTERSPERSE.deftext:
to scatter, place here and there

See inter- under Prefixes. To INTERSPERSE things is to scatter or sprinkle them between or among other things.

“Some red balls were INTERSPERSED among the black ones.”

“She INTERSPERSED some very funny jokes in an otherwise serious speech.”

In a slightly different sense, to INTERSPERSE something with other things is to supply it with these things here and there.

“He INTERSPERSED the black balls with some red ones.”

“The book was INTERSPERSED with many beautiful pictures.”

FACSIMILE.deftext:
a copy, reproduction

Note the pronunciation. The final e is sounded.

FACSIMILE is related to the word similar. Both come from a Latin word meaning like. A FACSIMILE is an exact, or almost exact, copy of a book, painting, letter, or the like.

“He printed a FACSIMILE of the Declaration of Independence that was identical in every detail with the original.”

“She wore a dress that was a close FACSIMILE of an expensive Paris design.”

The most common mistake on the Pretest is to choose original as the meaning of FACSIMILE. This is a confusion of a word with its opposite. A FACSIMILE is made from an original, but it is not the original itself.

CONSEQUENCE.deftext:
an effect, result; importance, value

A CONSEQUENCE is the effect or result of something that has gone before.

“His success was a direct CONSEQUENCE of his hard work.” CONSEQUENCE often suggests a bad or undesired result.

“If you steal this, you’ll have to accept the CONSEQUENCES when you are caught.”

“He didn’t consider all the CONSEQUENCES of his thoughtless behavior.”

In a different sense, CONSEQUENCE means importance, particularly with regard to the results that may come about from something.

“His refusal to come was of no CONSEQUENCE. We had a good time anyway.”

“She is a woman of great CONSEQUENCE in her community. Nothing is done without her approval.”

Other forms of the word: CONSEQUENTIAL, adj.

CANINE.deftext:
of or relating to dogs

CANINE means “of or like a dog.”

“A human’s CANINE teeth are pointed, like a dog’s teeth.”

“He followed his older brother around all day with CANINE devotion"-that is, he followed him like a dog following its master. CANINE is also a noun, meaning dog or “member of the dog family.”

“Poodles, collies, and terriers are all CANINES.”

“The fox is the only CANINE that can climb a tree.”

The most popular wrong answer on the Pretest is cat. The word which means “of or like a cat” is feline, not CANINE.

PLACID.deftext:
peaceful, calm, tranquil

PLACID means “free from disturbance,” calm, untroubled.

“Not the slightest ripple disturbed the PLACID surface of the lake.”

When used about people, PLACID means “having a peaceful nature,” and sometimes suggests a person who is too calm and lacking in feeling.

“She was so PLACID that not even the roar of the jet planes bothered her.”

Soft and weak are both sometimes chosen as the meaning of PLACID. They are both close, but not quite the same as peaceful, calm, untroubled. They might be chosen because of a confusion of PLACID with flaccid, which means weak, flabby.

Other forms of the word: PLACIDITY, n.

ELAPSE.deftext:
to pass, slip by, glide by

ELAPSE is almost always used about time. It means simply to pass, to go by.

“Twenty seconds ELAPSED between the two shots"- that is, the shots came twenty seconds apart.

“He returned after six months had ELAPSED.”

ELAPSE should not be confused with the similar verb lapse, which can be used about time, but it is more commonly used to mean “to fall into error” or “to go out of existence.” You can say “The insurance policy lapsed"; it doesn’t make sense, however, to say “The insurance policy ELAPSED.”

UPHOLD.deftext:
to support, approve

UPHOLD is made up of the two words hold and up. UPHOLD means just that: to hold up or support. UPHOLD can be used about physical things like a roof, but it is generally used about ideas, decisions, or beliefs.

“The lower court’s decision in the case was UPHELD by the higher court.”

“He tried to UPHOLD his family’s good reputation.”

“I do not UPHOLD actions which are dangerous to oneself or others.”

Put off is the most frequently marked wrong answer on the Pretest, probably because one meaning of hold up is to delay.

STRICKEN.deftext:
wounded, afflicted, overcome

STRICKEN comes from the word strike. Someone who is STRICKEN with something has been struck or struck down by it. The word is usually used about illness, sorrow, misfortune, or the like.

“She was STRICKEN with a terrible disease.”

“Several soldiers lay STRICKEN on the battlefield.”

“After the flood the Red Cross aided the STRICKEN families.”

Panic-STRICKEN means “overwhelmed with great fear.”

“The panic-STRICKEN people fled from the huge monster.”

STRICKEN is also used in other phrases like conscience-STRICKEN and grief-STRICKEN.

MONOTONOUS.deftext:
unchanging, boring, tedious, repetitious

See -ous under Suffixes. The mono part of MONOTONOUS comes from the Greek word for one. A monologue is a speech for one person; a monocle is an eyeglass worn in one eye only. The ton part of the word comes from the word tone. Something that is MONOTONOUS has only one tone; it doesn’t vary at all, and therefore it is boring and uninteresting.

“The scenery was rather MONOTONOUS; there was nothing but cornfields as far as you could see.”

“The book was impressive at first, but after a while its heavy style became rather MONOTONOUS.”

“She quickly became bored with the MONOTONOUS work on the assembly line in the factory.”

Other forms of the word: MONOTONY, n.

ELUDE.deftext:
to escape, evade, slip away, avoid

To ELUDE someone is to avoid or evade him, usually by means of cleverness or quickness.

“The criminal managed to ELUDE the police by hiding in the trunk of a car.”

“The halfback ELUDED several tackles with his clever moves.”

Things or ideas can ELUDE you, usually by being very difficult or hard to see.

“The answer ELUDED Bob. No matter how hard he tried he couldn’t quite think of it.”

“The change she made in the room was so small that it ELUDED my notice.”

Other forms of the word: ELUSIVE, adj.

questions.prompt: Do you go higher as you ASCEND?
Would a talking horse be UNCANNY?
Would a VIVID story be dull to read?
Can you INTERSPERSE apples with oranges?
Is a FACSIMILE generally more valuable than an original?
Is going to prison sometimes a CONSEQUENCE of committing a crime?
Is a cocker spaniel a member of the CANINE family?
Do PLACID people get angry easily?
Does it take a hundred years for a century to ELAPSE?
Would most people like their decisions to be UPHELD?
Would a grief-STRICKEN person be unhappy?
Would MONOTONOUS music be fascinating to listen to?
Has a person in prison ELUDED punishment for his crime?
The airplane fell from the sky and ASCENDED to the ground.
Her OUTLANDISH methods of teaching constantly got her into trouble with the principal.
She has an UNCANNY ability to predict the weather.
I have a VIVID picture in my mind of exactly how the room is going to look.
The governor NULLIFIED the contract with the firm because they were cheating the state.
His workday was INTERSPERSED with many chances to relax and regain his strength.
John could produce a reasonably good FACSIMILE of George Washington's signature.
When the automobile was invented, no one realized the CONSEQUENCES it would have on the American way of life.
We call them CANINE teeth because they resemble an elephant's tusks.
She put a nice PLACID pillow beneath his head to make him more comfortable.
They ELAPSED the afternoon with friends on a picnic in the woods.
The heavy rains UPHELD the game for over an hour.
The entire city was STRICKEN with the plague.
She was very MONOTONOUS with the children--always telling them jokes and thinking up games for them to play.
We ELUDED them by escaping through a secret passage.

INITIATIVE.deftext:
a first step, introductory action

To INITIATE something is to begin it, to set it in motion. An INITIATIVE is the first step or move designed to start a series of events. To do something “on your own INITIATIVE” means that you take this first step without being told to. To “have the INITIATIVE” means that you are in a position to take the first step.

INITIATIVE is also used for the readiness and the ability to INITIATE actions or projects, particularly if they are difficult or dangerous.

“He was a man of great INITIATIVE. He saw what needed to be done and did it.”

Other forms of the word: INITIATE, v.

LAX.deftext:
not strict, loose, careless, negligent

Someone or something that is LAX is not strict or severe enough, is careless or negligent.

“He was very LAX about doing his homework on time.”

“He got away with it because the rules were LAX.”

Sometimes LAX is used in the sense of loose, “not firm or tense.”

“He had a very LAX handshake.”

The noun from LAX is LAXITY.

“She blamed the increase in teenage crime on the LAXITY of modern parents.”

Other forms of the word: LAXITY, n.

RETORT.deftext:
a reply, sharp answer

A RETORT is a sharp or witty answer to something that has just been said.

“He gave a quick RETORT to the fellow’s insult.”

“She couldn’t think of a RETORT strong enough to show how angry she was.”

“His clever RETORTS made people laugh, but also got him into trouble.”

RETORT is also a verb.

“‘It’s none of your business,’ Jack RETORTED.”

“He RETORTED that she had no one to blame but herself.”

SHACKLE.deftext:
a chain, iron ring

SHACKLES are chains or iron rings that are put around a person’s arms or legs to keep him from moving.

“They kept the prisoner in SHACKLES.”

When SHACKLE is used as a verb, it means “to put SHACKLES on,” to chain.

“The convict was SHACKLED to a large post.”

SHACKLE is also used in a broader sense for anything that prevents freedom of thought, action, or progress.

“Unless you can throw off the SHACKLES of your ignorance you will never be successful.”

Usage: SHACKLE is usually used in the plural.

TRANSACT.deftext:
to carry out, conduct

TRANSACT means to carry on or do. The word is usually used about business.

“They TRANSACTED all their business in the morning.”

“It is impossible to TRANSACT business with a fool.”

TRANSACTION is the noun from TRANSACT. A TRANSACTION is a business deal.

“Many of the company’s TRANSACTIONS are with foreign firms.”

In the Pretest, change is often chosen as the meaning of TRANSACT, perhaps because TRANSACT looks like transform, which means to change.

ATTIRE.deftext:
clothing, clothes, dress

ATTIRE is another word for clothing, especially fancy or splendid clothing

“They were dressed in their best holiday ATTIRE.”

“His dirty jersey and ragged pants were not proper ATTIRE for the restaurant.”

ATTIRE is also a verb, meaning to clothe or dress.

“For her wedding, she was ATTIRED all in white.”

Appearance is often chosen as the meaning of ATTIRE. Your clothing is part of your appearance, but ATTIRE only has to do with your clothing, not your entire appearance.

Usage: ATTIRE is a literary word, and would be used more often in writing than in speech.

COMPEL.deftext:
to force

To COMPEL means to force. The word suggests strong pressure or authority being used on a person to do something.

“The blinding rain COMPELLED us to stop driving and pull over to the side of the road.”

“His serious illness COMPELLED him to resign from his job.”

“She felt COMPELLED to warn him of the danger involved in the experiment.”

“Her brilliant play COMPELLED the crowd’s attention.”

COMPELLING is the adjective from COMPEL and means “demanding attention, respect, or admiration.”

“There are COMPELLING reasons why you must agree to the plan immediately.”

“The novel was so COMPELLING that I was unable to put it down until I finished it.”

Other forms of the word: COMPELLING, adj.

EXCRUCIATING.deftext:
agonizing, extremely painful

EXCRUCIATING is related to the word crucify. EXCRUCIATING means almost unbearably painful, as if someone were driving nails through you.

“The pain from his broken shoulder was EXCRUCIATING for a couple of days until the bones began to heal.”

“She suffered EXCRUCIATING embarrassment whenever she had to stand up and recite in front of the class.”

“Sometimes I think nothing is more EXCRUCIATING than a toothache.”

FINITE.deftext:
limited, having boundaries

FINITE comes from the same Latin word as finish and final. All have to do with ends or ending. FINITE means “having an end,” limited.

“We cannot keep paying them forever; we have only a FINITE amount of money.”

Note that this does not mean we have a small amount of money. It simply means that we don’t have an unlimited amount of money.

“We should be able to find him; it’s a big city, but the number of people in it is still FINITE.”

The opposite of FINITE is INFINITE, endless, unlimited. See in-2 under Prefixes.

“We can do anything we want; the possibilities are INFINITE.”

“Some people believe that the universe is INFINITE; others believe it is FINITE.”

FUTILE.deftext:
useless, ineffective, fruitless

FUTILE means of no use, in vain. An action or plan that is FUTILE cannot have the result that is hoped for.

“He made a FUTILE attempt to push the car by himself, then gave up.”

“Realizing it was FUTILE to fight any longer, the enemy surrendered.”

“It is FUTILE to argue with him. He never changes his mind.”

The noun from FUTILE is FUTILITY, which means uselessness.

“Despite the FUTILITY of our actions, we kept trying to unlock the door.”

“I explained to him the FUTILITY of trying to start a fire with wet matches.”

Other forms of the word: FUTILITY, n.

MUTINOUS.deftext:
rebellious, ready to revolt, difficult to control

A MUTINY is a rebellion or revolt against people in authority. The word is particularly applied to soldiers or sailors who turn against their officers. MUTINOUS is the adjective from MUTINY. See -ous under Suffixes. Someone who is MUTINOUS is rebelling, or is ready to rebel, against the orders of his superiors.

“The soldiers became MUTINOUS over the rotten food they were forced to eat.”

MUTINOUS is also used in a broader sense to mean “difficult to control,” unruly.

“The teacher found it impossible to get the MUTINOUS child to sit still and stop pestering everyone.”

Other forms of the word: MUTINY, n.

SUPERLATIVE.deftext:
supreme, excellent

See super- under Prefixes. Something which is SUPERLATIVE is of the highest quality; it is extremely great or excellent.

“It was a SUPERLATIVE dinner. It may have been the best I have ever had.”

“Her SUPERLATIVE paintings have won many prizes.”

“We thought it had been a SUPERLATIVE achievement to finish the job on time.”

ATROCIOUS.deftext:
terrible, dreadful, wicked, cruel

ATROCIOUS means extremely wicked or barbaric.

“Everyone was shocked by the ATROCIOUS crime.”

“The company treated its workers ATROCIOUSLY-the conditions in the factory were almost inhuman.”

In a slightly different sense, ATROCIOUS also means extremely bad, awful.

“The movie was simply ATROCIOUS-I left after ten minutes.”

“He made an ATROCIOUS error that cost the company millions.”

The most commonly selected incorrect answer is remarkable. This may be due to confusion with the word precocious. Precocious means “having a talent which usually appears in an older person.” A precocious child would be remarkable; he wouldn’t usually be ATROCIOUS.

Other forms of the word: ATROCITY, n.

CAMOUFLAGE.deftext:
to disguise, mask, conceal

CAMOUFLAGE is both a verb and a noun. In the military, CAMOUFLAGE is the use of paint, tree branches, netting, or other materials to give a false appearance to something like a tank or a gun position. Thus, to CAMOUFLAGE something is to disguise it in order to hide it or to deceive someone.

“The color of many animals is a natural CAMOUFLAGE that keeps larger animals from seeing them.”

“His constant smile CAMOUFLAGED his real feelings.”

ENLIGHTEN.deftext:
to inform, instruct

The original meaning of ENLIGHTEN was “to supply with light.” Now the word is only used in the sense “to give knowledge"-that is, to free someone from the “darkness” of misunderstanding or ignorance.

“I know nothing about his background. Could you ENLIGHTEN me?”

“We tried to ENLIGHTEN him as to the nature of the problem, but he wouldn’t listen.”

Someone who is ENLIGHTENED is free from ignorance and superstition.

“The boss took a very ENLIGHTENED approach in dealing with his workers. He treated them as equals and never threatened them.”

The most commonly selected incorrect answer is amuse, possibly because the light part of ENLIGHTEN is thought to mean not serious.

Other forms of the word: ENLIGHTENED, adj. ENLIGHTENMENT, n.

ARISTOCRACY.deftext:
the nobility, upper class

ARISTOCRACY comes from Greek words meaning “rule by the best.” The basic meaning of ARISTOCRACY is “a form of government in which the best people rule.” In common use the word refers to the highest social class of a country, the noble families who are accustomed to ruling and having power.

“As members of the ARISTOCRACY, the noblemen were entitled to many things that the common people could not have.”

“The United States has never had an ARISTOCRACY or ruling class.”

Other forms of the word: ARISTOCRAT, n. ARISTOCRATIC, adj.

LUSTER.deftext:
brightness, sheen; brilliance, glory

LUSTER is the soft glow of light reflected off a polished surface.

“She rubbed the table with a special oil to increase its LUSTER.”

From this, LUSTER has come to mean brightness in the sense of glory, brilliance, distinction.

“The mere presence of the famous woman added LUSTER to the occasion.”

“This act of heroism added further LUSTER to his already great reputation.”

Other forms of the word: LUSTROUS, adj.

SUPERINTEND.deftext:
to manage, oversee, look after

To SUPERINTEND something is to have charge of it, to supervise the management of it.

“He was chosen to SUPERINTEND the running of the store.”

“There was only one person to SUPERINTEND the entire building.”

A SUPERINTENDENT is a person who manages something like a building or a school.

“If your heat goes off, call the building’s SUPERINTENDENT immediately.”

Other forms of the word: SUPERINTENDENT, n.

ZEAL.deftext:
eagerness, passion, enthusiasm

ZEAL is eager devotion to a cause, religion, idea, or the like.

“Despite the ZEAL of his supporters he lost the election.”

“His ZEAL for teaching young children is unmatched.”

“In his ZEAL to improve humanity he sometimes goes too far and offends people.”

Someone who feels a great deal of ZEAL for a cause or goal is ZEALOUS. ZEALOUS is pronounced zel’-as.

“Jane is a ZEALOUS defender of the rights of poor people.”

“The policemen were ZEALOUS in enforcing the new law.”

Other forms of the word: ZEALOT, n. ZEALOUS, adj.

SHIRK.deftext:
to avoid, dodge

SHIRK means “to try to escape from doing” something, usually because of laziness, fear, or simple dislike of the work to be done.

“He would like to SHIRK his homework, but he knows he has to do it.”

“I cannot SHIRK the responsibility for my mistake.”

A person who is lazy and tries to avoid doing a fair share of the work is called a SHIRKER.

“SHIRKERS always try to get somebody else to do their work for them.”

Other forms of the word: SHIRKER, n.

COMPASSION.deftext:
pity, sympathy

COMPASSION is a feeling of pity. If you have COMPASSION, you understand and share in the suffering or pain which someone else feels.

“She had COMPASSION for suffering animals, so people brought her their sick and unwanted cats and dogs.”

“He gave the beggar a quarter, not out of COMPASSION, but simply to get rid of him.”

Someone who feels COMPASSION is COMPASSIONATE.

“William gave Sally a COMPASSIONATE glance when her mother scolded her for being late again.”

Other forms of the word: COMPASSIONATE, adj.

RAMBLE.deftext:
to wander, roam

To RAMBLE is to wander about, to go from place to place, without any special aim.

“They RAMBLED across the countryside, stopping whenever they liked.”

The word is often applied to talking and writing that goes on and on without any point.

“He had a tendency to RAMBLE when he talked. He just couldn’t stick to the subject.”

“She RAMBLED on about her garden until everyone had fallen asleep.”

STENCH.deftext:
a stink, foul odor

A STENCH is a strong, foul odor, like the odor of something rotting.

“The meat created quite a STENCH after it was left out in the hot sun all day.”

“No one could stand the STENCH of the tobacco he used in his pipe.”

REMORSE.deftext:
regret, repentance

REMORSE is deep, bitter guilt and sorrow for having done wrong. It comes from a Latin word meaning “to bite again” and suggests a guilty feeling that is gnawing away at your conscience.

“I immediately felt REMORSE for having yelled at her.”

“The criminal showed no REMORSE for the murder.”

“Their REMORSE didn’t seem genuine. I don’t think they’re a bit sorry.”

Other forms of the word: REMORSEFUL, adj. REMORSELESS, adj.

FORMAT.deftext:
arrangement

FORMAT is related to the word form. The FORMAT is the general physical arrangement of something, particularly of a book or magazine.

“They changed the FORMAT of the magazine so that it was bigger and had more pictures.”

“They hoped the new FORMAT of the books would make them easier to read.”

The word can also be used about other kinds of arrangements, like that of a television show.

“The idea behind the show is good, but the FORMAT is all wrong.”

CHRONOLOGY.deftext:
time order

The chron part of CHRONOLOGY means time. It is found in the word chronograph (a stop watch), as well as in the words chronic and chronicle. A CHRONOLOGY is the order in which a particular series of events occurred.

“The detective tried to establish the CHRONOLOGY of the events that led up to the murder.”

A CHRONOLOGY is also a table or list which organizes things according to the time at which they occurred. Finally, CHRONOLOGY is the science that tries to establish accurate dates for past events.

CHRONOLOGICAL is the adjective from CHRONOLOGY. To put things “in CHRONOLOGICAL order” is to arrange them in the order of their time.

“He listed Shakespeare’s plays in CHRONOLOGICAL order.”

Other forms of the word: CHRONOLOGICAL, adj.

FEASIBLE.deftext:
possible, practicable; likely; suitable Something which is FEASIBLE is able to be done, is possible.

“It was hardly a FEASIBLE plan, considering the costs involved.”

“The most FEASIBLE solution is not necessarily the fairest one.”

FEASIBLE is also sometimes used to mean logical or likely.

“His excuse seemed FEASIBLE enough.”

The word can also mean “capable of being dealt with successfully,” suitable.

“They chose the most FEASIBLE route they could find for the new road.”

“Is sunlight a FEASIBLE source of energy?”

Other forms of the word: FEASIBILITY, n.

INTELLECT.deftext:
mind, understanding, reasoning

INTELLECT is related to the word intelligent. The INTELLECT is the reasoning power of the mind, as opposed to its feelings and instincts.

“He has a great INTELLECT, but he’s not a very pleasant person to know.”

“My INTELLECT tells me that this is the right decision, but I wish it could be otherwise.”

INTELLECT is also used to mean “a person with great reasoning powers.”

“The finest INTELLECTS in the country were present at the conference.”

INTELLECTUAL is an adjective formed from INTELLECT. It means “having to do with the INTELLECT.”

“He preferred INTELLECTUAL pursuits, such as reading and chess, to sports.”

Other forms of the word: INTELLECTUAL, adj., n.

PREVAIL.deftext:
to win, triumph; to be widespread; to persuade

To PREVAIL over or against means to win or gain victory.

“We PREVAILED over our enemies.”

Sometimes the word is used without over or against.

” ‘Justice will PREVAIL’ means that justice will finally win out.”

PREVAIL can also mean “to be common or widespread.”

“After weeks of rioting, a feeling of calm now PREVAILS in the city.”

To PREVAIL on or upon someone is to persuade him, often with some difficulty.

“We finally PREVAILED upon him to tell us the secret.”

“She PREVAILED on her father to let her use the car.”

Other forms of the word: PREVAILING, adj. PREVALENT, adj.

SHREWD.deftext:
clever, keen, astute

A SHREWD person has a great deal of cleverness and sound judgment, especially in practical matters.

“He’s a SHREWD judge of talent. He rarely makes a mistake about actors.”

“Several SHREWD businessmen bought all the land before oil was discovered there.”

SHREWD often contains a sense of trickiness in its meaning.

“The SHREWD salesman knew just how to get people to buy the worthless stock.”

People often think SHREWD means unpleasant, possibly because SHREWD is often used in a negative way about people who are tricky or dishonest. SHREWD might also be confused with the word shrew, which means “a bad-tempered woman.”
